books.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1:1
verses.text: Argument—In the former part of this book, from the first to the twelfth chapter, the progress of the two cities, the earthly and the heavenly, from Noah to Abraham, is exhibited from Holy Scripture: In the latter part, the progress of the heavenly alone, from Abraham to the kings of Israel, is the subject.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1:2
verses.text: Chapter 1—Whether, After the Deluge, from Noah to Abraham, Any Families Can Be Found Who Lived According to God.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1:3
verses.text: It is difficult to discover from Scripture, whether, after the deluge, traces of the holy city are continuous, or are so interrupted by intervening seasons of godlessness, that not a single worshipper of the one true God was found among men; because from Noah, who, with his wife, three sons, and as many daughters-in-law, achieved deliverance in the ark from the destruction of the deluge, down to Abraham, we do not find in the canonical books that the piety of any one is celebrated by express divine testimony, unless it be in the case of Noah, who commends with a prophetic benediction his two sons Shem and Japheth, while he beheld and foresaw what was long afterwards to happen.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1:4
verses.text: It was also by this prophetic spirit that, when his middle son—that is, the son who was younger than the first and older than the last born—had sinned against him, he cursed him not in his own person, but in his son's (his own grandson's), in the words, "Cursed be the lad Canaan; a servant shall he be unto his brethren".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1:5
verses.text: Now Canaan was born of Ham, who, so far from covering his sleeping father's nakedness, had divulged it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1:6
verses.text: For the same reason also he subjoins the blessing on his two other sons, the oldest and youngest, saying, "Blessed be the Lord God of Shem; and Canaan shall be his servant.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1:7
verses.text: God shall gladden Japheth, and he shall dwell in the houses of Shem".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 1:8
verses.text: And so, too, the planting of the vine by Noah, and his intoxication by its fruit, and his nakedness while he slept, and the other things done at that time, and recorded, are all of them pregnant with prophetic meanings, and veiled in mysteries.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—What Was Prophetically Prefigured in the Sons of Noah.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:2
verses.text: The things which then were hidden are now sufficiently revealed by the actual events which have followed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:3
verses.text: For who can carefully and intelligently consider these things without recognizing them accomplished in Christ? Shem, of whom Christ was born in the flesh, means "named".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:4
verses.text: And what is of greater name than Christ, the fragrance of whose name is now everywhere perceived, so that even prophecy sings of it beforehand, comparing it in the Song of Songs, to ointment poured forth? Is it not also in the houses of Christ, that is, in the churches, that the "enlargement" of the nations dwells? For Japheth means "enlargement".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:5
verses.text: And Ham (i-e:, hot), who was the middle son of Noah, and, as it were, separated himself from both, and remained between them, neither belonging to the first-fruits of Israel nor to the fullness of the Gentiles, what does he signify but the tribe of heretics, hot with the spirit, not of patience, but of impatience, with which the breasts of heretics are wont to blaze, and with which they disturb the peace of the saints? But even the heretics yield an advantage to those that make proficiency, according to the apostle's saying,  "There must also be heresies, that they which are approved may be made manifest among you".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:6
verses.text: Whence, too, it is elsewhere said, "The son that receives instruction will be wise, and he uses the foolish as his servant".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:7
verses.text: For while the hot restlessness of heretics stirs questions about many articles of the catholic faith, the necessity of defending them forces us both to investigate them more accurately, to understand them more clearly, and to proclaim them more earnestly; and the question mooted by an adversary becomes the occasion of instruction.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:8
verses.text: However, not only those who are openly separated from the church, but also all who glory in the Christian name, and at the same time lead abandoned lives, may without absurdity seem to be figured by Noah's middle son: for the passion of Christ, which was signified by that man's nakedness, is at once proclaimed by their profession, and dishonored by their wicked conduct.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:9
verses.text: Of such, therefore, it has been said, "By their fruits ye shall know them".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:10
verses.text: And therefore was Ham cursed in his son, he being, as it were, his fruit.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:11
verses.text: So, too, this son of his, Canaan, is fitly interpreted "their movement," which is nothing else than their work.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:12
verses.text: But Shem and Japheth, that is to say, the circumcision and uncircumcision, or, as the apostle otherwise calls them, the Jews and Greeks, but called and justified, having somehow discovered the nakedness of their father (which signifies the Saviour's passion), took a garment and laid it upon their backs, and entered backwards and covered their father's nakedness, without their seeing what their reverence hid.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:13
verses.text: For we both honor the passion of Christ as accomplished for us, and we hate the crime of the Jews who crucified Him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:14
verses.text: The garment signifies the sacrament, their backs the memory of things past: for the church celebrates the passion of Christ as already accomplished, and no longer to be looked forward to, now that Japheth already dwells in the habitations of Shem, and their wicked brother between them.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:15
verses.text: But the wicked brother is, in the person of his son (i-e:, his work), the boy, or slave, of his good brothers, when good men make a skillful use of bad men, either for the exercise of their patience or for their advancement in wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:16
verses.text: For the apostle testifies that there are some who preach Christ from no pure motives; "but," says he, "whether in pretence or in truth, Christ is preached; and I therein do rejoice, yea, and will rejoice".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:17
verses.text: For it is Christ Himself who planted the vine of which the prophet says, "The vine of the Lord of hosts is the house of Israel;" and He drinks of its wine, whether we thus understand that cup of which He says, "Can ye drink of the cup that I shall drink of?" and, "Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me," by which He obviously means His passion.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:18
verses.text: Or, as wine is the fruit of the vine, we may prefer to understand that from this vine, that is to say, from the race of Israel, He has assumed flesh and blood that He might suffer; "and he was drunken," that is, He suffered; "and was naked," that is, His weakness appeared in His suffering, as the apostle says, "though He was crucified through weakness".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:19
verses.text: Wherefore the same apostle says, "The weakness of God is stronger than men; and the foolishness of God is wiser than men".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:20
verses.text: And when to the expression "he was naked" Scripture adds "in his house," it elegantly intimates that Jesus was to suffer the cross and death at the hands of His own household, His own kith and kin, the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:21
verses.text: This passion of Christ is only externally and verbally professed by the reprobate, for what they profess, they do not understand.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:22
verses.text: But the elect hold in the inner man this so great mystery, and honor inwardly in the heart this weakness and foolishness of God.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:23
verses.text: And of this there is a figure in Ham going out to proclaim his father's nakedness; while Shem and Japheth, to cover or honor it, went in, that is to say, did it inwardly.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:24
verses.text: These secrets of divine Scripture we investigate as well as we can.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:25
verses.text: All will not accept our interpretation with equal confidence, but all hold it certain that these things were neither done nor recorded without some foreshadowing of future events, and that they are to be referred only to Christ and His church, which is the city of God, proclaimed from the very beginning of human history by figures which we now see everywhere accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:26
verses.text: From the blessing of the two sons of Noah, and the cursing of the middle son, down to Abraham, or for more than a thousand years, there is, as I have said, no mention of any righteous persons who worshipped God.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:27
verses.text: I do not therefore conclude that there were none; but it had been tedious to mention every one, and would have displayed historical accuracy rather than prophetic foresight.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:28
verses.text: The object of the writer of these sacred books, or rather of the Spirit of God in him, is not only to record the past, but to depict the future, so far as it regards the city of God; for whatever is said of those who are not its citizens, is given either for her instruction, or as a foil to enhance her glory.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:29
verses.text: Yet we are not to suppose that all that is recorded has some signification; but those things which have no signification of their own are interwoven for the sake of the things which are significant.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:30
verses.text: It is only the ploughshare that cleaves the soil; but to effect this, other parts of the plough are requisite.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:31
verses.text: It is only the strings in harps and other musical instruments which produce melodious sounds; but that they may do so, there are other parts of the instrument which are not indeed struck by those who sing, but are connected with the strings which are struck, and produce musical notes.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 2:32
verses.text: So in this prophetic history some things are narrated which have no significance, but are, as it were, the framework to which the significant things are attached.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—Of the Generations of the Three Sons of Noah.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:2
verses.text: We must therefore introduce into this work an explanation of the generations of the three sons of Noah, in so far as that may illustrate the progress in time of the two cities.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:3
verses.text: Scripture first mentions that of the youngest son, who is called Japheth: he had eight sons, and by two of these sons seven grandchildren, three by one son, four by the other; in all, fifteen descendants.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:4
verses.text: Ham, Noah's middle son, had four sons, and by one of them five grandsons, and by one of these two great-grandsons; in all, eleven.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:5
verses.text: After enumerating these, Scripture returns to the first of the sons, and says, "Cush begat Nimrod; he began to be a giant on the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:6
verses.text: He was a giant hunter against the Lord God: wherefore they say, As Nimrod the giant hunter against the Lord.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:7
verses.text: And the beginning of his kingdom was Babylon, Erech, Accad, and Calneh, in the land of Shinar.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:8
verses.text: Out of that land went forth Assur, and built Nineveh, and the city Rehoboth, and Calah, and Resen between Nineveh and Calah: this was a great city".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:9
verses.text: Now this Cush, father of the giant Nimrod, is the first-named among the sons of Ham, to whom five sons and two grandsons are ascribed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:10
verses.text: But he either begat this giant after his grandsons were born, or, which is more credible, Scripture speaks of him separately on account of his eminence; for mention is also made of his kingdom, which began with that magnificent city Babylon, and the other places, whether cities or districts, mentioned along with it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:11
verses.text: But what is recorded of the land of Shinar which belonged to Nimrod's kingdom, to wit, that Assur went forth from it and built Nineveh and the other cities mentioned with it, happened long after; but he takes occasion to speak of it here on account of the grandeur of the Assyrian kingdom, which was wonderfully extended by Ninus son of Belus, and founder of the great city Nineveh, which was named after him, Nineveh, from Ninus.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:12
verses.text: But Assur, father of the Assyrian, was not one of the sons of Ham, Noah's son, but is found among the sons of Shem, his eldest son.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:13
verses.text: Whence it appears that among Shem's offspring there arose men who afterwards took possession of that giant's kingdom, and advancing from it, founded other cities, the first of which was called Nineveh, from Ninus.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:14
verses.text: From him Scripture returns to Ham's other son, Mizraim; and his sons are enumerated, not as seven individuals, but as seven nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:15
verses.text: And from the sixth, as if from the sixth son, the race called the Philistines are said to have sprung; so that there are in all eight.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:16
verses.text: Then it returns again to Canaan, in whose person Ham was cursed; and his eleven sons are named.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:17
verses.text: Then the territories they occupied, and some of the cities, are named.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:18
verses.text: And thus, if we count sons and grandsons, there are thirty-one of Ham's descendants registered.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:19
verses.text: It remains to mention the sons of Shem, Noah's eldest son; for to him this genealogical narrative gradually ascends from the youngest.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:20
verses.text: But in the commencement of the record of Shem's sons there is an obscurity which calls for explanation, since it is closely connected with the object of our investigation.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:21
verses.text: For we read, "Unto Shem also, the father of all the children of Heber, the brother of Japheth the elder, were children born".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:22
verses.text: This is the order of the words: And to Shem was born Heber, even to himself, that is, to Shem himself was born Heber, and Shem is the father of all his children.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:23
verses.text: We are intended to understand that Shem is the patriarch of all his posterity who were to be mentioned, whether sons, grandsons, great-grandsons, or descendants at any remove.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:24
verses.text: For Shem did not beget Heber, who was indeed in the fifth generation from him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:25
verses.text: For Shem begat, among other sons, Arphaxad; Arphaxad begat Cainan, Cainan begat Salah, Salah begat Heber.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:26
verses.text: And it was with good reason that he was named first among Shem's offspring, taking precedence even of his sons, though only a grandchild of the fifth generation; for from him, as tradition says, the Hebrews derived their name, though the other etymology which derives the name from Abraham (as if Abrahews) may possibly be correct.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:27
verses.text: But there can be little doubt that the former is the right etymology, and that they were called after Heber, Heberews, and then, dropping a letter, Hebrews; and so was their language called Hebrew, which was spoken by none but the people of Israel among whom was the city of God, mysteriously prefigured in all the people, and truly present in the saints.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:28
verses.text: Six of Shem's sons then are first named, then four grandsons born to one of these sons; then it mentions another son of Shem, who begat a grandson; and his son, again, or Shem's great-grandson, was Heber.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:29
verses.text: And Heber begat two sons, and called the one Peleg, which means "dividing;" and Scripture subjoins the reason of this name, saying, "for in his days was the earth divided".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:30
verses.text: What this means will afterwards appear.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:31
verses.text: Heber's other son begat twelve sons; consequently all Shem's descendants are twenty-seven.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:32
verses.text: The total number of the progeny of the three sons of Noah is seventy-three, fifteen by Japheth, thirty-one by Ham, twenty-seven by Shem.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:33
verses.text: Then Scripture adds, "These are the sons of Shem, after their families, after their tongues, in their lands, after their nations".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:34
verses.text: And so of the whole number "These are the families of the sons of Noah after their generations, in their nations; and by these were the isles of the nations dispersed through the earth after the flood".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:35
verses.text: From which we gather that the seventy-three (or rather, as I shall presently show, seventy-two) were not individuals, but nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:36
verses.text: For in a former passage, when the sons of Japheth were enumerated, it is said in conclusion, "By these were the isles of the nations divided in their lands, every one after his language, in their tribes, and in their nations".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:37
verses.text: But nations are expressly mentioned among the sons of Ham, as I showed above.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:38
verses.text: "Mizraim begat those who are called Ludim;" and so also of the other seven nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:39
verses.text: And after enumerating all of them, it concludes, "These are the sons of Ham, in their families, according to their languages, in their territories, and in their nations".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:40
verses.text: The reason, then, why the children of several of them are not mentioned, is that they belonged by birth to other nations, and did not themselves become nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 3:41
verses.text: Why else is it, that though eight sons are reckoned to Japheth, the sons of only two of these are mentioned; and though four are reckoned to Ham, only three are spoken of as having sons; and though six are reckoned to Shem, the descendants of only two of these are traced? Did the rest remain childless? We cannot suppose so; but they did not produce nations so great as to warrant their being mentioned, but were absorbed in the nations to which they belonged by birth.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—Of the Diversity of Languages, and of the Founding of Babylon.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:2
verses.text: But though these nations are said to have been dispersed according to their languages, yet the narrator recurs to that time when all had but one language, and explains how it came to pass that a diversity of languages was introduced.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:3
verses.text: "The whole earth," he says, "was of one lip, and all had one speech.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:4
verses.text: And it came to pass, as they journeyed from the east, that they found a plain in the land of Shinar, and dwelt there.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:5
verses.text: And they said one to another, Come, and let us make bricks, and burn them thoroughly.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:6
verses.text: And they had bricks for stone, and slime for mortar.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:7
verses.text: And they said, Come, and let us build for ourselves a city, and a tower whose top shall reach the sky; and let us make us a name, before we be scattered abroad on the face of all the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:8
verses.text: And the Lord came down to see the city and the tower, which the children of men builded.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:9
verses.text: And the Lord God said, Behold, the people is one, and they have all one language; and this they begin to do: and now nothing will be restrained from them, which they have imagined to do.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:10
verses.text: Come, and let us go down, and confound there their language, that they may not understand one another's speech.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:11
verses.text: And God scattered them thence on the face of all the earth: and they left off to build the city and the tower.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:12
verses.text: Therefore the name of it is called Confusion; because the Lord did there confound the language of all the earth: and the Lord God scattered them thence on the face of all the earth".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:13
verses.text: This city, which was called Confusion, is the same as Babylon, whose wonderful construction Gentile history also notices.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:14
verses.text: For Babylon means Confusion.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:15
verses.text: Whence we conclude that the giant Nimrod was its founder, as had been hinted a little before, where Scripture, in speaking of him, says that the beginning of his kingdom was Babylon, that is, Babylon had a supremacy over the other cities as the metropolis and royal residence; although it did not rise to the grand dimensions designed by its proud and impious founder.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:16
verses.text: The plan was to make it so high that it should reach the sky, whether this was meant of one tower which they intended to build higher than the others, or of all the towers, which might be signified by the singular number, as we speak of "the soldier," meaning the army, and of the frog or the locust, when we refer to the whole multitude  of frogs and locusts in the plagues with which Moses smote the Egyptians.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:17
verses.text: But what did these vain and presumptuous men intend? How did they expect to raise this lofty mass against God, when they had built it above all the mountains and the clouds of the earth's atmosphere? What injury could any spiritual or material elevation do to God? The safe and true way to heaven is made by humility, which lifts up the heart to the Lord, not against Him; as this giant is said to have been a "hunter against the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:18
verses.text: This has been misunderstood by some through the ambiguity of the Greek word, and they have translated it, not "against the Lord," but "before the Lord;" for ἐναντίον means both "before" and "against".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:19
verses.text: In the Psalm this word is rendered, "Let us weep before the Lord our Maker".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:20
verses.text: The same word occurs in the book of Job, where it is written, "Thou hast broken into fury against the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:21
verses.text: And so this giant is to be recognized as a "hunter against the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:22
verses.text: And what is meant by the term "hunter" but deceiver, oppressor, and destroyer of the animals of the earth? He and his people therefore, erected this tower against the Lord, and so gave expression to their impious pride; and justly was their wicked intention punished by God, even though it was unsuccessful.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:23
verses.text: But what was the nature of the punishment? As the tongue is the instrument of domination, in it pride was punished; so that man, who would not understand God when He issued His commands, should be misunderstood when he himself gave orders.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 4:24
verses.text: Thus was that conspiracy disbanded, for each man retired from those he could not understand, and associated with those whose speech was intelligible; and the nations were divided according to their languages, and scattered over the earth as seemed good to God, who accomplished this in ways hidden from and incomprehensible to us.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—Of God's Coming Down to Confound the Languages of the Builders of the City.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5:2
verses.text: We read, "The Lord came down to see the city and the tower which the sons of men built:" it was not the sons of God, but that society which lived in a merely human way, and which we call the earthly city.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5:3
verses.text: God, who is always wholly everywhere, does not move locally; but He is said to descend when He does anything in the earth out of the usual course, which, as it were, makes His presence felt.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5:4
verses.text: And in the same way, He does not by "seeing" learn some new thing, for He cannot ever be ignorant of anything; but He is said to see and recognize, in time, that which He causes others to see and recognize.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5:5
verses.text: And therefore that city was not previously being seen as God made it be seen when He showed how offensive it was to Him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5:6
verses.text: We might, indeed, interpret God's descending to the city of the descent of His angels in whom He dwells; so that the following words, "And the Lord God said, Behold, they are all one race and of one language," and also what follows, "Come, and let us go down and confound their speech," are a recapitulation, explaining how the previously intimated "descent of the Lord" was accomplished.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5:7
verses.text: For if He had already gone down, why does He say, "Come, and let us go down and confound?"—words which seem to be addressed to the angels, and to intimate that He who was in the angels descended in their descent.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 5:8
verses.text: And the words most appropriately are, not, "Go ye down and confound," but, "Let us confound their speech;" showing that He so works by His servants, that they are themselves also fellow-laborers with God, as the apostle says, "For we are fellow-laborers with God".

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—What We are to Understand by God's Speaking to the Angels.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:2
verses.text: We might have supposed that the words uttered at the creation of man, "Let us," and not Let me, "make man," were addressed to the angels, had He not added "in our image;" but as we cannot believe that man was made in the image of angels, or that the image of God is the same as that of angels, it is proper to refer this expression to the plurality of the Trinity.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:3
verses.text: And yet this Trinity, being one God, even after saying "Let us make," goes on to say, "And God made man in His image," and not "Gods made," or "in their image".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:4
verses.text: And were there any difficulty in applying to the angels the words, "Come, and let us go down and confound their speech," we might refer the plural to the Trinity, as if the Father were addressing the Son and the Holy Spirit; but it rather belongs to the angels to approach God by holy movements, that is, by pious thoughts, and thereby to avail themselves of the unchangeable truth which rules in the court of heaven as their eternal law.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:5
verses.text: For they are not themselves the truth; but partaking in the creative truth, they are moved towards it as the fountain of life, that what they have not in themselves they may obtain  in it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:6
verses.text: And this movement of theirs is steady, for they never go back from what they have reached.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:7
verses.text: And to these angels God does not speak, as we speak to one another, or to God, or to angels, or as the angels speak to us, or as God speaks to us through them: He speaks to them in an ineffable manner of His own, and that which He says is conveyed to us in a manner suited to our capacity.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:8
verses.text: For the speaking of God antecedent and superior to all His works, is the immutable reason of His work: it has no noisy and passing sound, but an energy eternally abiding and producing results in time.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:9
verses.text: Thus He speaks to the holy angels; but to us, who are far off, He speaks otherwise.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:10
verses.text: When, however, we hear with the inner ear some part of the speech of God, we approximate to the angels.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:11
verses.text: But in this work I need not labor to give an account of the ways in which God speaks.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:12
verses.text: For either the unchangeable Truth speaks directly to the mind of the rational creature in some indescribable way, or speaks through the changeable creature, either presenting spiritual images to our spirit, or bodily voices to our bodily sense.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:13
verses.text: The words, "Nothing will be restrained from them which they have imagined to do," are assuredly not meant as an affirmation, but as an interrogation, such as is used by persons threatening, as e.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:14
verses.text: g.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:15
verses.text: , when Dido exclaims,  "They will not take arms and pursue?"  We are to understand the words as if it had been said, Shall nothing be restrained from them which they have imagined to do? From these three men, therefore, the three sons of Noah we mean, 73, or rather, as the catalogue will show, 72 nations and as many languages were dispersed over the earth, and as they increased filled even the islands.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:16
verses.text: But the nations multiplied much more than the languages.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 6:17
verses.text: For even in Africa we know several barbarous nations which have but one language; and who can doubt that, as the human race increased, men contrived to pass to the islands in ships?.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 7

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—Whether Even the Remotest Islands Received Their Fauna from the Animals Which Were Preserved, Through the Deluge, in the Ark.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 7:2
verses.text: There is a question raised about all those kinds of beasts which are not domesticated, nor are produced like frogs from the earth, but are propagated by male and female parents, such as wolves and animals of that kind; and it is asked how they could be found in the islands after the deluge, in which all the animals not in the ark perished, unless the breed was restored from those which were preserved in pairs in the ark.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 7:3
verses.text: It might, indeed, be said that they crossed to the islands by swimming, but this could only be true of those very near the mainland; whereas there are some so distant, that we fancy no animal could swim to them.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 7:4
verses.text: But if men caught them and took them across with themselves, and thus propagated these breeds in their new abodes, this would not imply an incredible fondness for the chase.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 7:5
verses.text: At the same time, it cannot be denied that by the intervention of angels they might be transferred by God's order or permission.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 7:6
verses.text: If, however, they were produced out of the earth as at their first creation, when God said, "Let the earth bring forth the living creature," this makes it more evident that all kinds of animals were preserved in the ark, not so much for the sake of renewing the stock, as of prefiguring the various nations which were to be saved in the church; this, I say, is more evident, if the earth brought forth many animals in islands to which they could not cross over.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—Whether Certain Monstrous Races of Men are Derived from the Stock of Adam or Noah's Sons.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:2
verses.text: It is also asked whether we are to believe that certain monstrous races of men, spoken of in secular history, have sprung from Noah's sons, or rather, I should say, from that one man from whom they themselves were descended.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:3
verses.text: For it is reported that some have one eye in the middle of the forehead; some, feet turned backwards from the heel; some, a double sex, the right breast like a man, the left like a woman, and that they alternately beget and bring forth: others are said to have no mouth, and to breathe only through the nostrils; others are but a cubit high, and are therefore called by the Greeks "Pigmies:" they say that in some places the women conceive in their fifth year, and do not live beyond their eighth.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:4
verses.text: So, too, they tell of a race who have two feet but only one leg, and are of marvellous swiftness, though they do not bend the knee: they are called Skiopodes, because in the hot weather they lie down on their backs and shade themselves with their feet.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:5
verses.text: Others are said to have no head, and their eyes in their shoulders; and other  human or quasi-human races are depicted in mosaic in the harbor esplanade of Carthage, on the faith of histories of rarities.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:6
verses.text: What shall I say of the Cynocephali, whose dog-like head and barking proclaim them beasts rather than men? But we are not bound to believe all we hear of these monstrosities.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:7
verses.text: But whoever is anywhere born a man, that is, a rational, mortal animal, no matter what unusual appearance he presents in color, movement, sound, nor how peculiar he is in some power, part, or quality of his nature, no Christian can doubt that he springs from that one protoplast.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:8
verses.text: We can distinguish the common human nature from that which is peculiar, and therefore wonderful.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:9
verses.text: The same account which is given of monstrous births in individual cases can be given of monstrous races.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:10
verses.text: For God, the Creator of all, knows where and when each thing ought to be, or to have been created, because He sees the similarities and diversities which can contribute to the beauty of the whole.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:11
verses.text: But He who cannot see the whole is offended by the deformity of the part, because he is blind to that which balances it, and to which it belongs.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:12
verses.text: We know that men are born with more than four fingers on their hands or toes on their feet: this is a smaller matter; but far from us be the folly of supposing that the Creator mistook the number of a man's fingers, though we cannot account for the difference.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:13
verses.text: And so in cases where the divergence from the rule is greater.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:14
verses.text: He whose works no man justly finds fault with, knows what He has done.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:15
verses.text: At Hippo-Diarrhytus there is a man whose hands are crescent-shaped, and have only two fingers each, and his feet similarly formed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:16
verses.text: If there were a race like him, it would be added to the history of the curious and wonderful.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:17
verses.text: Shall we therefore deny that this man is descended from that one man who was first created? As for the Androgyni, or Hermaphrodites, as they are called, though they are rare, yet from time to time there appears persons of sex so doubtful, that it remains uncertain from which sex they take their name; though it is customary to give them a masculine name, as the more worthy.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:18
verses.text: For no one ever called them Hermaphroditesses.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:19
verses.text: Some years ago, quite within my own memory, a man was born in the East, double in his upper, but single in his lower half—having two heads, two chests, four hands, but one body and two feet like an ordinary man; and he lived so long that many had an opportunity of seeing him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:20
verses.text: But who could enumerate all the human births that have differed widely from their ascertained parents? As, therefore, no one will deny that these are all descended from that one man, so all the races which are reported to have diverged in bodily appearance from the usual course which nature generally or almost universally preserves, if they are embraced in that definition of man as rational and mortal animals, unquestionably trace their pedigree to that one first father of all.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:21
verses.text: We are supposing these stories about various races who differ from one another and from us to be true; but possibly they are not: for if we were not aware that apes, and monkeys, and sphinxes are not men, but beasts, those historians would possibly describe them as races of men, and flaunt with impunity their false and vainglorious discoveries.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:22
verses.text: But supposing they are men of whom these marvels are recorded, what if God has seen fit to create some races in this way, that we might not suppose that the monstrous births which appear among ourselves are the failures of that wisdom whereby He fashions the human nature, as we speak of the failure of a less perfect workman? Accordingly, it ought not to seem absurd to us, that as in individual races there are monstrous births, so in the whole race there are monstrous races.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 8:23
verses.text: Wherefore, to conclude this question cautiously and guardedly, either these things which have been told of some races have no existence at all; or if they do exist, they are not human races; or if they are human, they are descended from Adam.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 9

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—Whether We are to Believe in the Antipodes.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 9:2
verses.text: But as to the fable that there are Antipodes, that is to say, men on the opposite side of the earth, where the sun rises when it sets to us, men who walk with their feet opposite ours, that is on no ground credible.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 9:3
verses.text: And, indeed, it is not affirmed that this has been learned by historical knowledge, but by scientific conjecture, on the ground that the earth is suspended within the concavity of the sky, and that it has as much room on the one side of it as on the other: hence they say that the part which is beneath must also be inhabited.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 9:4
verses.text: But they do not remark that, although it be supposed or scientifically demonstrated that the world is of a round and spherical form, yet it does not follow that the other side of the earth is bare of water; nor even, though it be bare, does it immediately follow that it is peopled.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 9:5
verses.text: For Scripture, which proves the truth of its historical statements by the accomplishment of its prophecies, gives no false information; and it is too absurd to say, that some men might have  taken ship and traversed the whole wide ocean, and crossed from this side of the world to the other, and that thus even the inhabitants of that distant region are descended from that one first man.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 9:6
verses.text: Wherefore let us seek if we can find the city of God that sojourns on earth among those human races who are catalogued as having been divided into seventy-two nations and as many languages.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 9:7
verses.text: For it continued down to the deluge and the ark, and is proved to have existed still among the sons of Noah by their blessings, and chiefly in the eldest son Shem; for Japheth received this blessing, that he should dwell in the tents of Shem.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—Of the Genealogy of Shem, in Whose Line the City of God is Preserved Till the Time of Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:2
verses.text: It is necessary, therefore, to preserve the series of generations descending from Shem, for the sake of exhibiting the city of God after the flood; as before the flood it was exhibited in the series of generations descending from Seth.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:3
verses.text: And therefore does divine Scripture, after exhibiting the earthly city as Babylon or "Confusion," revert to the patriarch Shem, and recapitulate the generations from him to Abraham, specifying besides, the year in which each father begat the son that belonged to this line, and how long he lived.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:4
verses.text: And unquestionably it is this which fulfills the promise I made, that it should appear why it is said of the sons of Heber, "The name of the one was Peleg, for in his days the earth was divided".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:5
verses.text: For what can we understand by the division of the earth, if not the diversity of languages? And, therefore, omitting the other sons of Shem, who are not concerned in this matter, Scripture gives the genealogy of those by whom the line runs on to Abraham, as before the flood those are given who carried on the line to Noah from Seth.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:6
verses.text: Accordingly this series of generations begins thus: "These are the generations of Shem: Shem was an hundred years old, and begat Arphaxad two years after the flood.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:7
verses.text: And Shem lived after he begat Arphaxad five hundred years, and begat sons and daughters".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:8
verses.text: In like manner it registers the rest, naming the year of his life in which each begat the son who belonged to that line which extends to Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:9
verses.text: It specifies, too, how many years he lived thereafter, begetting sons and daughters, that we may not childishly suppose that the men named were the only men, but may understand how the population increased, and how regions and kingdoms so vast could be populated by the descendants of Shem; especially the kingdom of Assyria, from which Ninus subdued the surrounding nations, reigning with brilliant prosperity, and bequeathing to his descendants a vast but thoroughly consolidated empire, which held together for many centuries.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:10
verses.text: But to avoid needless prolixity, we shall mention not the number of years each member of this series lived, but only the year of his life in which he begat his heir, that we may thus reckon the number of years from the flood to Abraham, and may at the same time leave room to touch briefly and cursorily upon some other matters necessary to our argument.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:11
verses.text: In the second year, then, after the flood, Shem when he was a hundred years old begat Arphaxad; Arphaxad when he was 135 years old begat Cainan; Cainan when he was 130 years begat Salah.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:12
verses.text: Salah himself, too, was the same age when he begat Eber.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:13
verses.text: Eber lived 134 years, and begat Peleg, in whose days the earth was divided.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:14
verses.text: Peleg himself lived 130 years, and begat Reu; and Reu lived 132 years, and begat Serug; Serug 130, and begat Nahor; and Nahor 79, and begat Terah; and Terah 70, and begat Abram, whose name God afterwards changed into Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:15
verses.text: There are thus from the flood to Abraham 1072 years, according to the Vulgate or Septuagint versions.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:16
verses.text: In the Hebrew copies far fewer years are given; and for this either no reason or a not very credible one is given.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:17
verses.text: When, therefore, we look for the city of God in these seventy-two nations, we cannot affirm that while they had but one lip, that is, one language, the human race had departed from the worship of the true God, and that genuine godliness had survived only in those generations which descend from Shem through Arphaxad and reach to Abraham; but from the time when they proudly built a tower to heaven, a symbol of godless exaltation, the city or society of the wicked becomes apparent.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:18
verses.text: Whether it was only disguised before, or non-existent; whether both cities remained after the flood,—the godly in the two sons of Noah who were blessed, and in their posterity, and the ungodly in the cursed son and his descendants, from whom sprang that mighty hunter against the Lord,—is not easily determined.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:19
verses.text: For possibly—and certainly this is more credible—there were despisers of God among the descendants of the two sons, even before Babylon was founded, and worshippers of God among the descendants of Ham.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:20
verses.text: Certainly neither race was ever obliterated from earth.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:21
verses.text: For in both the Psalms in which it is said, "They are all gone aside,  they are altogether become filthy; there is none that doeth good, no, not one," we read further, "Have all the workers of iniquity no knowledge? who eat up my people as they eat bread, and call not upon the Lord".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:22
verses.text: There was then a people of God even at that time.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:23
verses.text: And therefore the words, "There is none that doeth good, no, not one," were said of the sons of men, not of the sons of God.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 10:24
verses.text: For it had been previously said, "God looked down from heaven upon the sons of men, to see if any understood and sought after God;" and then follow the words which demonstrate that all the sons of men, that is, all who belong to the city which lives according to man, not according to God, are reprobate.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—That the Original Language in Use Among Men Was that Which Was Afterwards Called Hebrew, from Heber, in Whose Family It Was Preserved When the Confusion of Tongues Occurred.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:2
verses.text: Wherefore, as the fact of all using one language did not secure the absence of sin-infected men from the race,—for even before the deluge there was one language, and yet all but the single family of just Noah were found worthy of destruction by the flood,—so when the nations, by a prouder godlessness, earned the punishment of the dispersion and the confusion of tongues, and the city of the godless was called Confusion or Babylon, there was still the house of Heber in which the primitive language of the race survived.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:3
verses.text: And therefore, as I have already mentioned, when an enumeration is made of the sons of Shem, who each founded a nation, Heber is first mentioned, although he was of the fifth generation from Shem.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:4
verses.text: And because, when the other races were divided by their own peculiar languages, his family preserved that language which is not unreasonably believed to have been the common language of the race, it was on this account thenceforth named Hebrew.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:5
verses.text: For it then became necessary to distinguish this language from the rest by a proper name; though, while there was only one, it had no other name than the language of man, or human speech, it alone being spoken by the whole human race.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:6
verses.text: Some one will say: If the earth was divided by languages in the days of Peleg, Heber's son, that language, which was formerly common to all, should rather have been called after Peleg.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:7
verses.text: But we are to understand that Heber himself gave to his son this name Peleg, which means Division; because he was born when the earth was divided, that is, at the very time of the division, and that this is the meaning of the words, "In his days the earth was divided".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:8
verses.text: For unless Heber had been still alive when the languages were multiplied, the language which was preserved in his house would not have been called after him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:9
verses.text: We are induced to believe that this was the primitive and common language, because the multiplication and change of languages was introduced as a punishment, and it is fit to ascribe to the people of God an immunity from this punishment.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:10
verses.text: Nor is it without significance that this is the language which Abraham retained, and that he could not transmit it to all his descendants, but only to those of Jacob's line, who distinctively and eminently constituted God's people, and received His covenants, and were Christ's progenitors according to the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:11
verses.text: In the same way, Heber himself did not transmit that language to all his posterity, but only to the line from which Abraham sprang.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:12
verses.text: And thus, although it is not expressly stated, that when the wicked were building Babylon there was a godly seed remaining, this indistinctness is intended to stimulate research rather than to elude it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:13
verses.text: For when we see that originally there was one common language, and that Heber is mentioned before all Shem's sons, though he belonged to the fifth generation from him, and that the language which the patriarchs and prophets used, not only in their conversation, but in the authoritative language of Scripture, is called Hebrew, when we are asked where that primitive and common language was preserved after the confusion of tongues, certainly, as there can be no doubt that those among whom it was preserved were exempt from the punishment it embodied, what other suggestion can we make, than that it survived in the family of him whose name it took, and that this is no small proof of the righteousness of this family, that the punishment with which the other families were visited did not fall upon it?  But yet another question is mooted: How did Heber and his son Peleg each found a nation, if they had but one language? For no doubt the Hebrew nation propagated from Heber through Abraham, and becoming through him a great people, is one nation.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:14
verses.text: How, then, are all the sons of the three branches of Noah's family enumerated as founding a nation each, if Heber and Peleg did not so? It is very probable that the giant Nimrod founded also his nation, and that  Scripture has named him separately on account of the extraordinary dimensions of his empire and of his body, so that the number of seventy-two nations remains.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:15
verses.text: But Peleg was mentioned, not because he founded a nation (for his race and language are Hebrew), but on account of the critical time at which he was born, all the earth being then divided.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:16
verses.text: Nor ought we to be surprised that the giant Nimrod lived to the time in which Babylon was founded and the confusion of tongues occurred, and the consequent division of the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:17
verses.text: For though Heber was in the sixth generation from Noah, and Nimrod in the fourth, it does not follow that they could not be alive at the same time.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:18
verses.text: For when the generations are few, they live longer and are born later; but when they are many, they live a shorter time, and come into the world earlier.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:19
verses.text: We are to understand that, when the earth was divided, the descendants of Noah who are registered as founders of nations were not only already born, but were of an age to have immense families, worthy to be called tribes or nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:20
verses.text: And therefore we must by no means suppose that they were born in the order in which they were set down; otherwise, how could the twelve sons of Joktan, another son of Heber's, and brother of Peleg, have already founded nations, if Joktan was born, as he is registered, after his brother Peleg, since the earth was divided at Peleg's birth? We are therefore to understand that, though Peleg is named first, he was born long after Joktan, whose twelve sons had already families so large as to admit of their being divided by different languages.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:21
verses.text: There is nothing extraordinary in the last born being first named: of the sons of Noah, the descendants of Japheth are first named; then the sons of Ham, who was the second son; and last the sons of Shem, who was the first and oldest.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:22
verses.text: Of these nations the names have partly survived, so that at this day we can see from whom they have sprung, as the Assyrians from Assur, the Hebrews from Heber, but partly have been altered in the lapse of time, so that the most learned men, by profound research in ancient records, have scarcely been able to discover the origin, I do not say of all, but of some of these nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:23
verses.text: There is, for example, nothing in the name Egyptians to show that they are descended from Misraim, Ham's son, nor in the name Ethiopians to show a connection with Cush, though such is said to be the origin of these nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 11:24
verses.text: And if we take a general survey of the names, we shall find that more have been changed than have remained the same.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—Of the Era in Abraham's Life from Which a New Period in the Holy Succession Begins.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:2
verses.text: Let us now survey the progress of the city of God from the era of the patriarch Abraham, from whose time it begins to be more conspicuous, and the divine promises which are now fulfilled in Christ are more fully revealed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:3
verses.text: We learn, then, from the intimations of holy Scripture, that Abraham was born in the country of the Chaldeans, a land belonging to the Assyrian empire.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:4
verses.text: Now, even at that time impious superstitions were rife with the Chaldeans, as with other nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:5
verses.text: The family of Terah, to which Abraham belonged, was the only one in which the worship of the true God survived, and the only one, we may suppose, in which the Hebrew language was preserved; although Joshua the son of Nun tells us that even this family served other gods in Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:6
verses.text: The other descendants of Heber gradually became absorbed in other races and other languages.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:7
verses.text: And thus, as the single family of Noah was preserved through the deluge of water to renew the human race, so, in the deluge of superstition that flooded the whole world, there remained but the one family of Terah in which the seed of God's city was preserved.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:8
verses.text: And as, when Scripture has enumerated the generations prior to Noah, with their ages, and explained the cause of the flood before God began to speak to Noah about the building of the ark, it is said, "These are the generations of Noah;" so also now, after enumerating the generations from Shem, Noah's son, down to Abraham, it then signalizes an era by saying, "These are the generations of Terah: Terah begat Abram, Nahor, and Haran; and Haran begat Lot.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:9
verses.text: And Haran died before his father Terah in the land of his nativity, in Ur of the Chaldees.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:10
verses.text: And Abram and Nahor took them wives: the name of Abram's wife was Sarai; and the name of Nahor's wife Milcah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah, and the father of Iscah".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 12:11
verses.text: This Iscah is supposed to be the same as Sarah, Abraham's wife.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—Why, in the Account of Terah's Emigration, on His Forsaking the Chaldeans and Passing Over into Mesopotamia, No Mention is Made of His Son Nahor.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:2
verses.text: Next it is related how Terah with his family left the region of the Chaldeans and came into Mesopotamia, and dwelt in Haran.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:3
verses.text: But  nothing is said about one of his sons called Nahor, as if he had not taken him along with him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:4
verses.text: For the narrative runs thus: "And Terah took Abram his son, and Lot the son of Haran, his son's son, and Sarah his daughter-in-law, his son Abram's wife, and led them forth out of the region of the Chaldeans to go into the land of Canaan; and he came into Haran, and dwelt there".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:5
verses.text: Nahor and Milcah his wife are nowhere named here.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:6
verses.text: But afterwards, when Abraham sent his servant to take a wife for his son Isaac, we find it thus written: "And the servant took ten camels of the camels of his lord, and of all the goods of his lord, with him; and arose, and went into Mesopotamia, into the city of Nahor".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:7
verses.text: This and other testimonies of this sacred history show that Nahor, Abraham's brother, had also left the region of the Chaldeans, and fixed his abode in Mesopotamia, where Abraham dwelt with his father.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:8
verses.text: Why, then, did the Scripture not mention him, when Terah with his family went forth out of the Chaldean nation and dwelt in Haran, since it mentions that he took with him not only Abraham his son, but also Sarah his daughter-in-law, and Lot his grandson? The only reason we can think of is, that perhaps he had lapsed from the piety of his father and brother, and adhered to the superstition of the Chaldeans, and had afterwards emigrated thence, either through penitence, or because he was persecuted as a suspected person.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:9
verses.text: For in the book called Judith, when Holofernes, the enemy of the Israelites, inquired what kind of nation that might be, and whether war should be made against them, Achior, the leader of the Ammonites, answered him thus: "Let our lord now hear a word from the mouth of thy servant, and I will declare unto thee the truth concerning the people which dwelleth near thee in this hill country, and there shall no lie come out of the mouth of thy servant.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:10
verses.text: For this people is descended from the Chaldeans, and they dwelt heretofore in Mesopotamia, because they would not follow the gods of their fathers, which were glorious in the land of the Chaldeans, but went out of the way of their ancestors, and adored the God of heaven, whom they knew; and they cast them out from the face of their gods, and they fled into Mesopotamia, and dwelt there many days.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:11
verses.text: And their God said to them, that they should depart from their habitation, and go into the land of Canaan; and they dwelt," etc.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:12
verses.text: , as Achior the Ammonite narrates.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 13:13
verses.text: Whence it is manifest that the house of Terah had suffered persecution from the Chaldeans for the true piety with which they worshipped the one and true God.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 14

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—Of the Years of Terah, Who Completed His Lifetime in Haran.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 14:2
verses.text: On Terah's death in Mesopotamia, where he is said to have lived 205 years, the promises of God made to Abraham now begin to be pointed out; for thus it is written: "And the days of Terah in Haran were two hundred and five years, and he died in Haran".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 14:3
verses.text: This is not to be taken as if he had spent all his days there, but that he there completed the days of his life, which were two hundred and five years: otherwise it would not be known how many years Terah lived, since it is not said in what year of his life he came into Haran; and it is absurd to suppose that, in this series of generations, where it is carefully recorded how many years each one lived, his age was the only one not put on record.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 14:4
verses.text: For although some whom the same Scripture mentions have not their age recorded, they are not in this series, in which the reckoning of time is continuously indicated by the death of the parents and the succession of the children.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 14:5
verses.text: For this series, which is given in order from Adam to Noah, and from him down to Abraham, contains no one without the number of the years of his life.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15—Of the Time of the Migration of Abraham, When, According to the Commandment of God, He Went Out from Haran.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:2
verses.text: When, after the record of the death of Terah, the father of Abraham, we next read, "And the Lord said to Abram, Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father's house," etc.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:3
verses.text: , it is not to be supposed, because this follows in the order of the narrative, that it also followed in the chronological order of events.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:4
verses.text: For if it were so, there would be an insoluble difficulty.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:5
verses.text: For after these words of God which were spoken to Abraham, the Scripture says: "And Abram departed, as the Lord had spoken unto him; and Lot went with him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:6
verses.text: Now Abraham was seventy-five years old when he departed out of Haran".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:7
verses.text: How can this be true if he departed from Haran after his father's death? For when Terah was seventy years old, as is intimated above, he begat Abraham; and if to this number we add the seventy-five years which Abraham reckoned when he went out of Haran, we get 145 years.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:8
verses.text: Therefore that  was the number of the years of Terah, when Abraham departed out of that city of Mesopotamia; for he had reached the seventy-fifth year of his life, and thus his father, who begat him in the seventieth year of his life, had reached, as was said, his 145th.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:9
verses.text: Therefore he did not depart thence after his father's death, that is, after the 205 years his father lived; but the year of his departure from that place, seeing it was his seventy-fifth, is inferred beyond a doubt to have been the 145th of his father, who begat him in his seventieth year.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:10
verses.text: And thus it is to be understood that the Scripture, according to its custom, has gone back to the time which had already been passed by the narrative; just as above, when it had mentioned the grandsons of Noah, it said that they were in their nations and tongues; and yet afterwards, as if this also had followed in order of time, it says, "And the whole earth was of one lip, and one speech for all".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:11
verses.text: How, then, could they be said to be in their own nations and according to their own tongues, if there was one for all; except because the narrative goes back to gather up what it had passed over? Here, too, in the same way, after saying, "And the days of Terah in Haran were 205 years, and Terah died in Haran," the Scripture, going back to what had been passed over in order to complete what had been begun about Terah, says, "And the Lord said to Abram, Get thee out of thy country," etc.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:12
verses.text: After which words of God it is added, "And Abram departed, as the Lord spake unto him; and Lot went with him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:13
verses.text: But Abram was seventy-five years old when he departed out of Haran".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:14
verses.text: Therefore it was done when his father was in the 145th year of his age; for it was then the seventy-fifth of his own.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:15
verses.text: But this question is also solved in another way, that the seventy-five years of Abraham when he departed out of Haran are reckoned from the year in which he was delivered from the fire of the Chaldeans, not from that of his birth, as if he was rather to be held as having been born then.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:16
verses.text: Now the blessed Stephen, in narrating these things in the Acts of the Apostles, says: "The God of glory appeared unto our father Abraham, when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Charran, and said unto him, Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father's house, and come into the land which I will show thee".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:17
verses.text: According to these words of Stephen, God spoke to Abraham, not after the death of his father, who certainly died in Haran, where his son also dwelt with him, but before he dwelt in that city, although he was already in Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:18
verses.text: Therefore he had already departed from the Chaldeans.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:19
verses.text: So that when Stephen adds, "Then Abraham went out of the land of the Chaldeans, and dwelt in Charran," this does not point out what took place after God spoke to him (for it was not after these words of God that he went out of the land of the Chaldeans, since he says that God spoke to him in Mesopotamia), but the word "then" which he uses refers to that whole period from his going out of the land of the Chaldeans and dwelling in Haran.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:20
verses.text: Likewise in what follows, "And thenceforth, when his father was dead, he settled him in this land, wherein ye now dwell, and your fathers," he does not say, after his father was dead he went out from Haran; but thenceforth he settled him here, after his father was dead.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:21
verses.text: It is to be understood, therefore, that God had spoken to Abraham when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Haran; but that he came to Haran with his father, keeping in mind the precept of God, and that he went out thence in his own seventy-fifth year, which was his father's 145th.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:22
verses.text: But he says that his settlement in the land of Canaan, not his going forth from Haran, took place after his father's death; because his father was already dead when he purchased the land, and personally entered on possession of it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:23
verses.text: But when, on his having already settled in Mesopotamia, that is, already gone out of the land of the Chaldeans, God says, "Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father's house," this means, not that he should cast out his body from thence, for he had already done that, but that he should tear away his soul.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:24
verses.text: For he had not gone out from thence in mind, if he was held by the hope and desire of returning,—a hope and desire which was to be cut off by God's command and help, and by his own obedience.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 15:25
verses.text: It would indeed be no incredible supposition that afterwards, when Nahor followed his father, Abraham then fulfilled the precept of the Lord, that he should depart out of Haran with Sarah his wife and Lot his brother's son.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 16

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16—Of the Order and Nature of the Promises of God Which Were Made to Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 16:2
verses.text: God's promises made to Abraham are now to be considered; for in these the oracles of our God, that is, of the true God, began to appear more openly concerning the godly  people, whom prophetic authority foretold.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 16:3
verses.text: The first of these reads thus: "And the Lord said unto Abram, Get thee out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and from thy father's house, and go into a land that I will show thee: and I will make of thee a great nation, and I will bless thee and magnify thy name; and thou shall be blessed: and I will bless them that bless thee, and curse them that curse thee: and in thee shall all tribes of the earth be blessed".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 16:4
verses.text: Now it is to be observed that two things are promised to Abraham, the one, that his seed should possess the land of Canaan, which is intimated when it is said, "Go into a land that I will show thee, and I will make of thee a great nation;" but the other far more excellent, not about the carnal but the spiritual seed, through which he is the father, not of the one Israelite nation, but of all nations who follow the footprints of his faith, which was first promised in these words, "And in thee shall all tribes of the earth be blessed".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 16:5
verses.text: Eusebius thought this promise was made in Abraham's seventy-fifth year, as if soon after it was made Abraham had departed out of Haran because the Scripture cannot be contradicted in which we read, "Abram was seventy and five years old when he departed out of Haran".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 16:6
verses.text: But if this promise was made in that year, then of course Abraham was staying in Haran with his father; for he could not depart thence unless he had first dwelt there.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 16:7
verses.text: Does this, then, contradict what Stephen says, "The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham, when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Charran?" But it is to be understood that the whole took place in the same year,—both the promise of God before Abraham dwelt in Haran, and his dwelling in Haran, and his departure thence,—not only because Eusebius in the Chronicles reckons from the year of this promise, and shows that after 430 years the exodus from Egypt took place, when the law was given, but because the Apostle Paul also mentions it.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17—Of the Three Most Famous Kingdoms of the Nations, of Which One, that is the Assyrian, Was Already Very Eminent When Abraham Was Born.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:2
verses.text: During the same period there were three famous kingdoms of the nations, in which the city of the earth-born, that is, the society of men living according to man under the domination of the fallen angels, chiefly flourished, namely, the three kingdoms of Sicyon, Egypt, and Assyria.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:3
verses.text: Of these, Assyria was much the most powerful and sublime; for that king Ninus, son of Belus, had subdued the people of all Asia except India.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:4
verses.text: By Asia I now mean not that part which is one province of this greater Asia, but what is called Universal Asia, which some set down as the half, but most as the third part of the whole world,—the three being Asia, Europe, and Africa, thereby making an unequal division.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:5
verses.text: For the part called Asia stretches from the south through the east even to the north; Europe from the north even to the west; and Africa from the west even to the south.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:6
verses.text: Thus we see that two, Europe and Africa, contain one half of the world, and Asia alone the other half.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:7
verses.text: And these two parts are made by the circumstance, that there enters between them from the ocean all the Mediterranean water, which makes this great sea of ours.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:8
verses.text: So that, if you divide the world into two parts, the east and the west, Asia will be in the one, and Europe and Africa in the other.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:9
verses.text: So that of the three kingdoms then famous, one, namely Sicyon, was not under the Assyrians, because it was in Europe; but as for Egypt, how could it fail to be subject to the empire which ruled all Asia with the single exception of India? In Assyria, therefore, the dominion of the impious city had the pre-eminence.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:10
verses.text: Its head was Babylon,—an earth-born city, most fitly named, for it means confusion.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:11
