verses.text: There Ninus reigned after the death of his father Belus, who first had reigned there sixty-five years.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 17:12
verses.text: His son Ninus, who, on his father's death, succeeded to the kingdom, reigned fifty-two years, and had been king forty-three years when Abraham was born, which was about the 1200th year before Rome was founded, as it were another Babylon in the west.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 18

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18—Of the Repeated Address of God to Abraham, in Which He Promised the Land of Canaan to Him and to His Seed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 18:2
verses.text: Abraham, then, having departed out of Haran in the seventy-fifth year of his own age, and in the hundred and forty-fifth of his father's, went with Lot, his brother's son, and Sarah his wife, into the land of Canaan, and came even to Sichem, where again he received the divine oracle, of which it is thus written: "And the Lord appeared unto Abram, and said unto him, Unto thy seed will I give this land".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 18:3
verses.text: Nothing is promised here about that seed in which he is made the  father of all nations, but only about that by which he is the father of the one Israelite nation; for by this seed that land was possessed.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 19—Of the Divine Preservation of Sarah's Chastity in Egypt, When Abraham Had Called Her Not His Wife But His Sister.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:2
verses.text: Having built an altar there, and called upon God, Abraham proceeded thence and dwelt in the desert, and was compelled by pressure of famine to go on into Egypt.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:3
verses.text: There he called his wife his sister, and told no lie.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:4
verses.text: For she was this also, because she was near of blood; just as Lot, on account of the same nearness, being his brother's son, is called his brother.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:5
verses.text: Now he did not deny that she was his wife, but held his peace about it, committing to God the defence of his wife's chastity, and providing as a man against human wiles; because if he had not provided against the danger as much as he could, he would have been tempting God rather than trusting in Him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:6
verses.text: We have said enough about this matter against the calumnies of Faustus the Manichaean.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:7
verses.text: At last what Abraham had expected the Lord to do took place.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:8
verses.text: For Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who had taken her to him as his wife, restored her to her husband on being severely plagued.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 19:9
verses.text: And far be it from us to believe that she was defiled by lying with another; because it is much more credible that, by these great afflictions, Pharaoh was not permitted to do this.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 20

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 20—Of the Parting of Lot and Abraham, Which They Agreed to Without Breach of Charity.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 20:2
verses.text: On Abraham's return out of Egypt to the place he had left, Lot, his brother's son, departed from him into the land of Sodom, without breach of charity.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 20:3
verses.text: For they had grown rich, and began to have many herdmen of cattle, and when these strove together, they avoided in this way the pugnacious discord of their families.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 20:4
verses.text: Indeed, as human affairs go, this cause might even have given rise to some strife between themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 20:5
verses.text: Consequently these are the words of Abraham to Lot, when taking precaution against this evil, "Let there be no strife between me and thee, and between my herdmen and thy herdmen; for we be brethren.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 20:6
verses.text: Behold, is not the whole land before thee? Separate thyself from me: if thou wilt go to the left hand, I will go to the right; or if thou wilt go to the right hand, I will go to the left".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 20:7
verses.text: From this, perhaps, has arisen a pacific custom among men, that when there is any partition of earthly things, the greater should make the division, the less the choice.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 21—Of the Third Promise of God, by Which He Assured the Land of Canaan to Abraham and His Seed in Perpetuity.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:2
verses.text: Now, when Abraham and Lot had separated, and dwelt apart, owing to the necessity of supporting their families, and not to vile discord, and Abraham was in the land of Canaan, but Lot in Sodom, the Lord said to Abraham in a third oracle, "Lift up thine eyes, and look from the place where thou now art, to the north, and to Africa, and to the east, and to the sea; for all the land which thou seest, to thee will I give it, and to thy seed for ever.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:3
verses.text: And I will make thy seed as the dust of the earth: if any one can number the dust of the earth, thy seed shall also be numbered.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:4
verses.text: Arise, and walk through the land, in the length of it, and in the breadth of it; for unto thee will I give it".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:5
verses.text: It does not clearly appear whether in this promise that also is contained by which he is made the father of all nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:6
verses.text: For the clause, "And I will make thy seed as the dust of the earth," may seem to refer to this, being spoken by that figure the Greeks call hyperbole, which indeed is figurative, not literal.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:7
verses.text: But no person of understanding can doubt in what manner the Scripture uses this and other figures.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:8
verses.text: For that figure (that is, way of speaking) is used when what is said is far larger than what is meant by it; for who does not see how incomparably larger the number of the dust must be than that of all men can be from Adam himself down to the end of the world? How much greater, then, must it be than the seed of Abraham,—not only that pertaining to the nation of Israel, but also that which is and shall be according to the imitation of faith in all nations of the whole wide world! For that seed is indeed very small in comparison with the multitude of the wicked, although even those few of themselves make an innumerable multitude, which by a hyperbole is compared to the dust of the earth.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:9
verses.text: Truly that multitude which was promised to Abraham is not innumerable to God, although to man; but to God not even the dust of the earth is so.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:10
verses.text: Further, the promise here made may be understood not only of the nation of Israel, but of the whole seed of Abraham, which may be fitly compared to the dust for  multitude, because regarding it also there is the promise of many children, not according to the flesh, but according to the spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:11
verses.text: But we have therefore said that this does not clearly appear, because the multitude even of that one nation, which was born according to the flesh of Abraham through his grandson Jacob, has increased so much as to fill almost all parts of the world.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:12
verses.text: Consequently, even it might by hyperbole be compared to the dust for multitude, because even it alone is innumerable by man.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:13
verses.text: Certainly no one questions that only that land is meant which is called Canaan.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:14
verses.text: But that saying, "To thee will I give it, and to thy seed for ever," may move some, if by "for ever" they understand "to eternity".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 21:15
verses.text: But if in this passage they take "for ever" thus, as we firmly hold it means that the beginning of the world to come is to be ordered from the end of the present, there is still no difficulty, because, although the Israelites are expelled from Jerusalem, they still remain in other cities in the land of Canaan, and shall remain even to the end; and when that whole land is inhabited by Christians, they also are the very seed of Abraham.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 22

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 22:1
verses.text: Chapter 22—Of Abraham's Overcoming the Enemies of Sodom, When He Delivered Lot from Captivity and Was Blessed by Melchizedek the Priest.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 22:2
verses.text: Having received this oracle of promise, Abraham migrated, and remained in another place of the same land, that is, beside the oak of Mamre, which was Hebron.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 22:3
verses.text: Then on the invasion of Sodom, when five kings carried on war against four, and Lot was taken captive with the conquered Sodomites, Abraham delivered him from the enemy, leading with him to battle three hundred and eighteen of his home-born servants, and won the victory for the kings of Sodom, but would take nothing of the spoils when offered by the king for whom he had won them.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 22:4
verses.text: He was then openly blessed by Melchizedek, who was priest of God Most High, about whom many and great things are written in the epistle which is inscribed to the Hebrews, which most say is by the Apostle Paul, though some deny this.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 22:5
verses.text: For then first appeared the sacrifice which is now offered to God by Christians in the whole wide world, and that is fulfilled which long after the event was said by the prophet to Christ, who was yet to come in the flesh, "Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek,"—that is to say, not after the order of Aaron, for that order was to be taken away when the things shone forth which were intimated beforehand by these shadows.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:1
verses.text: Chapter 23—Of the Word of the Lord to Abraham, by Which It Was Promised to Him that His Posterity Should Be Multiplied According to the Multitude of the Stars; On Believing Which He Was Declared Justified While Yet in Uncircumcision.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:2
verses.text: The word of the Lord came to Abraham in a vision also.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:3
verses.text: For when God promised him protection and exceeding great reward, he, being solicitous about posterity, said that a certain Eliezer of Damascus, born in his house, would be his heir.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:4
verses.text: Immediately he was promised an heir, not that house-born servant, but one who was to come forth of Abraham himself; and again a seed innumerable, not as the dust of the earth, but as the stars of heaven,—which rather seems to me a promise of a posterity exalted in celestial felicity.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:5
verses.text: For, so far as multitude is concerned, what are the stars of heaven to the dust of the earth, unless one should say the comparison is like inasmuch as the stars also cannot be numbered? For it is not to be believed that all of them can be seen.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:6
verses.text: For the more keenly one observes them, the more does he see.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:7
verses.text: So that it is to be supposed some remain concealed from the keenest observers, to say nothing of those stars which are said to rise and set in another part of the world most remote from us.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:8
verses.text: Finally, the authority of this book condemns those like Aratus or Eudoxus, or any others who boast that they have found out and written down the complete number of the stars.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:9
verses.text: Here, indeed, is set down that sentence which the apostle quotes in order to commend the grace of God, "Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him for righteousness;" lest the circumcision should glory, and be unwilling to receive the uncircumcised nations to the faith of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 23:10
verses.text: For at the time when he believed, and his faith was counted to him for righteousness, Abraham had not yet been circumcised.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:1
verses.text: Chapter 24—Of the Meaning of the Sacrifice Abraham Was Commanded to Offer When He Supplicated to Be Taught About Those Things He Had Believed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:2
verses.text: In the same vision, God in speaking to him also says, "I am God that brought thee out  of the region of the Chaldees, to give thee this land to inherit it".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:3
verses.text: And when Abram asked whereby he might know that he should inherit it, God said to him, "Take me an heifer of three years old, and a she-goat of three years old, and a ram of three years old, and a turtle-dove, and a pigeon.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:4
verses.text: And he took unto him all these, and divided them in the midst, and laid each piece one against another; but the birds divided he not.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:5
verses.text: And the fowls came down," as it is written, "on the carcasses, and Abram sat down by them.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:6
verses.text: But about the going down of the sun, great fear fell upon Abram; and, lo, an horror of great darkness fell upon him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:7
verses.text: And He said unto Abram, Know of a surety that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land not theirs, and they shall reduce them to servitude and shall afflict them four hundred years: but the nation whom they shall serve will I judge; and afterward shall they come out hither with great substance.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:8
verses.text: And thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace; kept in a good old age.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:9
verses.text: But in the fourth generation they shall come hither again: for the iniquity of the Amorites is not yet full.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:10
verses.text: And when the sun was setting, there was a flame, and a smoking furnace, and lamps of fire, that passed through between those pieces.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:11
verses.text: In that day the Lord made a covenant with Abram, saying, Unto thy seed will I give this land, from the river of Egypt unto the great river Euphrates: the Kenites, and the Kenizzites, and the Kadmonites, and the Hittites, and the Perizzites, and the Rephaims, and the Amorites, and the Canaanites, and the Hivites, and the Girgashites, and the Jebusites".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:12
verses.text: All these things were said and done in a vision from God; but it would take long, and would exceed the scope of this work, to treat of them exactly in detail.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:13
verses.text: It is enough that we should know that, after it was said Abram believed in God, and it was counted to him for righteousness, he did not fail in faith in saying, "Lord God, whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it?" for the inheritance of that land was promised to him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:14
verses.text: Now he does not say, How shall I know, as if he did not yet believe; but he says, "Whereby shall I know," meaning that some sign might be given by which he might know the manner of those things which he had believed, just as it is not for lack of faith the Virgin Mary says, "How shall this be, seeing I know not a man?" for she inquired as to the way in which that should take place which she was certain would come to pass.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:15
verses.text: And when she asked this, she was told, "The Holy Ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:16
verses.text: Here also, in fine, a symbol was given, consisting of three animals, a heifer, a she-goat, and a ram, and two birds, a turtle-dove and pigeon, that he might know that the things which he had not doubted should come to pass were to happen in accordance with this symbol.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:17
verses.text: Whether, therefore, the heifer was a sign that the people should be put under the law, the she-goat that the same people was to become sinful, the ram that they should reign (and these animals are said to be of three years old for this reason, that there are three remarkable divisions of time, from Adam to Noah, and from him to Abraham, and from him to David, who, on the rejection of Saul, was first established by the will of the Lord in the kingdom of the Israelite nation: in this third division, which extends from Abraham to David, that people grew up as if passing through the third age of life), or whether they had some other more suitable meaning, still I have no doubt whatever that spiritual things were prefigured by them as well as by the turtle-dove and pigeon.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:18
verses.text: And it is said, "But the birds divided he not," because carnal men are divided among themselves, but the spiritual not at all, whether they seclude themselves from the busy conversation of men, like the turtle-dove, or dwell among them, like the pigeon; for both birds are simple and harmless, signifying that even in the Israelite people, to which that land was to be given, there would be individuals who were children of the promise, and heirs of the kingdom that is to remain in eternal felicity.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:19
verses.text: But the fowls coming down on the divided carcasses represent nothing good, but the spirits of this air, seeking some food for themselves in the division of carnal men.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:20
verses.text: But that Abraham sat down with them, signifies that even amid these divisions of the carnal, true believers shall persevere to the end.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:21
verses.text: And that about the going down of the sun great fear fell upon Abraham and a horror of great darkness, signifies that about the end of this world believers shall be in great perturbation and tribulation, of which the Lord said in the gospel, "For then shall be great tribulation, such as was not from the beginning".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:22
verses.text: But what is said to Abraham, "Know of a surety that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land not theirs, and they shall reduce them to servitude, and shall afflict them 400 years," is most clearly a prophecy about the people  of Israel which was to be in servitude in Egypt.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:23
verses.text: Not that this people was to be in that servitude under the oppressive Egyptians for 400 years, but it is foretold that this should take place in the course of those 400 years.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:24
verses.text: For as it is written of Terah the father of Abraham, "And the days of Terah in Haran were 205 years," not because they were all spent there, but because they were completed there, so it is said here also, "And they shall reduce them to servitude, and shall afflict them 400 years," for this reason, because that number was completed, not because it was all spent in that affliction.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:25
verses.text: The years are said to be 400 in round numbers, although they were a little more,—whether you reckon from this time, when these things were promised to Abraham, or from the birth of Isaac, as the seed of Abraham, of which these things are predicted.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:26
verses.text: For, as we have already said above, from the seventy-fifth year of Abraham, when the first promise was made to him, down to the exodus of Israel from Egypt, there are reckoned 430 years, which the apostle thus mentions: "And this I say, that the covenant confirmed by God, the law, which was made 430 years after, cannot disannul, that it should make the promise of none effect".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:27
verses.text: So then these 430 years might be called 400, because they are not much more, especially since part even of that number had already gone by when these things were shown and said to Abraham in vision, or when Isaac was born in his father's 100th year, twenty-five years after the first promise, when of these 430 years there now remained 405, which God was pleased to call 400 No one will doubt that the other things which follow in the prophetic words of God pertain to the people of Israel.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:28
verses.text: When it is added, "And when the sun was now setting there was a flame, and lo, a smoking furnace, and lamps of fire, which passed through between those pieces," this signifies that at the end of the world the carnal shall be judged by fire.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:29
verses.text: For just as the affliction of the city of God, such as never was before, which is expected to take place under Antichrist, was signified by Abraham's horror of great darkness about the going down of the sun, that is, when the end of the world draws nigh,—so at the going down of the sun, that is, at the very end of the world, there is signified by that fire the day of judgment, which separates the carnal who are to be saved by fire from those who are to be condemned in the fire.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:30
verses.text: And then the covenant made with Abraham particularly sets forth the land of Canaan, and names eleven tribes in it from the river of Egypt even to the great river Euphrates.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 24:31
verses.text: It is not then from the great river of Egypt, that is, the Nile, but from a small one which separates Egypt from Palestine, where the city of Rhinocorura is.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 25

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 25:1
verses.text: Chapter 25—Of Sarah's Handmaid, Hagar, Whom She Herself Wished to Be Abraham's Concubine.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 25:2
verses.text: And here follow the times of Abraham's sons, the one by Hagar the bond maid, the other by Sarah the free woman, about whom we have already spoken in the previous book.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 25:3
verses.text: As regards this transaction, Abraham is in no way to be branded as guilty concerning this concubine, for he used her for the begetting of progeny, not for the gratification of lust; and not to insult, but rather to obey his wife, who supposed it would be solace of her barrenness if she could make use of the fruitful womb of her handmaid to supply the defect of her own nature, and by that law of which the apostle says, "Likewise also the husband hath not power of his own body, but the wife," could, as a wife, make use of him for childbearing by another, when she could not do so in her own person.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 25:4
verses.text: Here there is no wanton lust, no filthy lewdness.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 25:5
verses.text: The handmaid is delivered to the husband by the wife for the sake of progeny, and is received by the husband for the sake of progeny, each seeking, not guilty excess, but natural fruit.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 25:6
verses.text: And when the pregnant bond woman despised her barren mistress, and Sarah, with womanly jealousy, rather laid the blame of this on her husband, even then Abraham showed that he was not a slavish lover, but a free begetter of children, and that in using Hagar he had guarded the chastity of Sarah his wife, and had gratified her will and not his own,—had received her without seeking, had gone in to her without being attached, had impregnated without loving her,—for he says, "Behold thy maid is in thy hands: do to her as it pleaseth thee;" a man able to use women as a man should,—his wife temperately, his handmaid compliantly, neither intemperately!.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:1
verses.text: Chapter 26—Of God's Attestation to Abraham, by Which He Assures Him, When Now Old, of a Son by the Barren Sarah, and Appoints Him the Father of the Nations, and Seals His Faith in the Promise by the Sacrament of Circumcision.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:2
verses.text: After these things Ishmael was born of Hagar; and Abraham might think that in him  was fulfilled what God had promised him, saying, when he wished to adopt his home-born servant, "This shall not be thine heir; but he that shall come forth of thee, he shall be thine heir".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:3
verses.text: Therefore, lest he should think that what was promised was fulfilled in the handmaid's son, "when Abram was ninety years old and nine, God appeared to him, and said unto him, I am God; be well-pleasing in my sight, and be without complaint, and I will make my covenant between me and thee, and will fill thee exceedingly".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:4
verses.text: Here there are more distinct promises about the calling of the nations in Isaac, that is, in the son of the promise, by which grace is signified, and not nature; for the son is promised from an old man and a barren old woman.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:5
verses.text: For although God effects even the natural course of procreation, yet where the agency of God is manifest, through the decay or failure of nature, grace is more plainly discerned.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:6
verses.text: And because this was to be brought about, not by generation, but by regeneration, circumcision was enjoined now, when a son was promised of Sarah.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:7
verses.text: And by ordering all, not only sons, but also home-born and purchased servants to be circumcised, he testifies that this grace pertains to all.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:8
verses.text: For what else does circumcision signify than a nature renewed on the putting off of the old? And what else does the eighth day mean than Christ, who rose again when the week was completed, that is, after the Sabbath? The very names of the parents are changed: all things proclaim newness, and the new covenant is shadowed forth in the old.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:9
verses.text: For what does the term old covenant imply but the concealing of the new? And what does the term new covenant imply but the revealing of the old? The laughter of Abraham is the exultation of one who rejoices, not the scornful laughter of one who mistrusts.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:10
verses.text: And those words of his in his heart, "Shall a son be born to me that am an hundred years old? and shall Sarah, that is ninety years old, bear?" are not the words of doubt, but of wonder.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:11
verses.text: And when it is said, "And I will give to thee, and to thy seed after thee, the land in which thou art a stranger, all the land of Canaan, for an everlasting possession," if it troubles any one whether this is to be held as fulfilled, or whether its fulfilment may still be looked for, since no kind of earthly possession can be everlasting for any nation whatever, let him know that the word translated everlasting, by our writers is what the Greeks term αἰώ·νιον, which is derived from αἰὼ·ν, the Greek for saeculum, an age.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:12
verses.text: But the Latins have not ventured to translate this by secular, lest they should change the meaning into something widely different.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 26:13
verses.text: For many things are called secular which so happen in this world as to pass away even in a short time; but what is termed αἰω·νιον either has no end, or lasts to the very end of this world.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:1
verses.text: Chapter 27—Of the Male, Who Was to Lose His Soul If He Was Not Circumcised on the Eighth Day, Because He Had Broken God's Covenant.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:2
verses.text: When it is said, "The male who is not circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin, that soul shall be cut off from his people, because he hath broken my covenant," some may be troubled how that ought to be understood, since it can be no fault of the infant whose life it is said must perish; nor has the covenant of God been broken by him, but by his parents, who have not taken care to circumcise him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:3
verses.text: But even the infants, not personally in their own life, but according to the common origin of the human race, have all broken God's covenant in that one in whom all have sinned.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:4
verses.text: Now there are many things called God's covenants besides those two great ones, the old and the new, which any one who pleases may read and know.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:5
verses.text: For the first covenant, which was made with the first man, is just this: "In the day ye eat thereof, ye shall surely die".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:6
verses.text: Whence it is written in the book called Ecclesiasticus, "All flesh waxeth old as doth a garment.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:7
verses.text: For the covenant from the beginning is, Thou shall die the death".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:8
verses.text: Now, as the law was more plainly given afterward, and the apostle says, "Where no law is, there is no prevarication," on what supposition is what is said in the psalm true, "I accounted all the sinners of the earth prevaricators," except that all who are held liable for any sin are accused of dealing deceitfully (prevaricating) with some law? If on this account, then, even the infants are, according to the true belief, born in sin, not actual but original, so that we confess they have need of grace for the remission of sins, certainly it must be acknowledged that in the same sense in which they are sinners they are also prevaricators of that law which was given in Paradise, according to the truth of both scriptures, "I accounted all the sinners of the earth prevaricators," and "Where no law is, there is no prevarication".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:9
verses.text: And thus, be  cause circumcision was the sign of regeneration, and the infant, on account of the original sin by which God's covenant was first broken, was not undeservedly to lose his generation unless delivered by regeneration, these divine words are to be understood as if it had been said, Whoever is not born again, that soul shall perish from his people, because he hath broken my covenant, since he also has sinned in Adam with all others.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:10
verses.text: For had He said, Because he hath broken this my covenant, He would have compelled us to understand by it only this of circumcision; but since He has not expressly said what covenant the infant has broken, we are free to understand Him as speaking of that covenant of which the breach can be ascribed to an infant.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:11
verses.text: Yet if any one contends that it is said of nothing else than circumcision, that in it the infant has broken the covenant of God because, he is not circumcised, he must seek some method of explanation by which it may be understood without absurdity (such as this) that he has broken the covenant, because it has been broken in him although not by him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 27:12
verses.text: Yet in this case also it is to be observed that the soul of the infant, being guilty of no sin of neglect against itself, would perish unjustly, unless original sin rendered it obnoxious to punishment.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:1
verses.text: Chapter 28—Of the Change of Name in Abraham and Sarah, Who Received the Gift of Fecundity When They Were Incapable of Regeneration Owing to the Barrenness of One, and the Old Age of Both.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:2
verses.text: Now when a promise so great and clear was made to Abraham, in which it was so plainly said to him, "I have made thee a father of many nations, and I will increase thee exceedingly, and I will make nations of thee, and kings shall go forth of thee.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:3
verses.text: And I will give thee a son of Sarah; and I will bless him, and he shall become nations, and kings of nations shall be of him,"—a promise which we now see fulfilled in Christ,—from that time forward this couple are not called in Scripture, as formerly, Abram and Sarai, but Abraham and Sarah, as we have called them from the first, for every one does so now.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:4
verses.text: The reason why the name of Abraham was changed is given: "For," He says, "I have made thee a father of many nations".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:5
verses.text: This, then, is to be understood to be the meaning of Abraham; but Abram, as he was formerly called, means "exalted father".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:6
verses.text: The reason of the change of Sarah's name is not given; but as those say who have written interpretations of the Hebrew names contained in these books, Sarah means "my princess," and Sarai "strength".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:7
verses.text: Whence it is written in the Epistle to the Hebrews, "Through faith also Sarah herself received strength to conceive seed".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:8
verses.text: For both were old, as the Scripture testifies; but she was also barren, and had ceased to menstruate, so that she could no longer bear children even if she had not been barren.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:9
verses.text: Further, if a woman is advanced in years, yet still retains the custom of women, she can bear children to a young man, but not to an old man, although that same old man can beget, but only of a young woman; as after Sarah's death Abraham could of Keturah, because he met with her in her lively age.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:10
verses.text: This, then, is what the apostle mentions as wonderful, saying, besides, that Abraham's body was now dead; because at that age he was no longer able to beget children of any woman who retained now only a small part of her natural vigor.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:11
verses.text: Of course we must understand that his body was dead only to some purposes, not to all; for if it was so to all, it would no longer be the aged body of a living man, but the corpse of a dead one.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 28:12
verses.text: Although that question, how Abraham begot children of Keturah, is usually solved in this way, that the gift of begetting which he received from the Lord, remained even after the death of his wife, yet I think that solution of the question which I have followed is preferable, because, although in our days an old man of a hundred years can beget children of no woman, it was not so then, when men still lived so long that a hundred years did not yet bring on them the decrepitude of old age.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:1
verses.text: Chapter 29—Of the Three Men or Angels, in Whom the Lord is Related to Have Appeared to Abraham at the Oak of Mamre.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:2
verses.text: God appeared again to Abraham at the oak of Mamre in three men, who it is not to be doubted were angels, although some think that one of them was Christ, and assert that He was visible before He put on flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:3
verses.text: Now it belongs to the divine power, and invisible, incorporeal, and incommutable nature, without changing itself at all, to appear even to mortal men, not by what it is, but by what is subject to it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:4
verses.text: And what is not subject to it? Yet if they try to establish that one of these three was Christ by the fact that, although he saw three, he addressed the Lord in the singular, as it is written, "And, lo, three men stood by him: and, when he saw them, he ran  to meet them from the tent-door, and worshipped toward the ground, and said, Lord, if I have found favor before thee," etc.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:5
verses.text: ; why do they not advert to this also, that when two of them came to destroy the Sodomites, while Abraham still spoke to one, calling him Lord, and interceding that he would not destroy the righteous along with the wicked in Sodom, Lot received these two in such a way that he too in his conversation with them addressed the Lord in the singular? For after saying to them in the plural, "Behold, my lords, turn aside into your servant's house," etc.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:6
verses.text: , yet it is afterwards said, "And the angels laid hold upon his hand, and the hand of his wife, and the hands of his two daughters, because the Lord was merciful unto him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:7
verses.text: And it came to pass, whenever they had led him forth abroad, that they said, Save thy life; look not behind thee, neither stay thou in all this region: save thyself in the mountain, lest thou be caught.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:8
verses.text: And Lot said unto them, I pray thee, Lord, since thy servant hath found grace in thy sight," etc.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:9
verses.text: And then after these words the Lord also answered him in the singular, although He was in two angels, saying, "See, I have accepted thy face," etc.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:10
verses.text: This makes it much more credible that both Abraham in the three men and Lot in the two recognized the Lord, addressing Him in the singular number, even when they were addressing men; for they received them as they did for no other reason than that they might minister human refection to them as men who needed it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:11
verses.text: Yet there was about them something so excellent, that those who showed them hospitality as men could not doubt that God was in them as He was wont to be in the prophets, and therefore sometimes addressed them in the plural, and sometimes God in them in the singular.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:12
verses.text: But that they were angels the Scripture testifies, not only in this book of Genesis, in which these transactions are related, but also in the Epistle to the Hebrews, where in praising hospitality it is said, "For thereby some have entertained angels unawares".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:13
verses.text: By these three men, then, when a son Isaac was again promised to Abraham by Sarah, such a divine oracle was also given that it was said, "Abraham shall become a great and numerous nation, and all the nations of the earth shall be blessed in him".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 29:14
verses.text: And here these two things, are promised with the utmost brevity and fullness,—the nation of Israel according to the flesh, and all nations according to faith.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 30

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 30:1
verses.text: Chapter 30—Of Lot's Deliverance from Sodom, and Its Consumption by Fire from Heaven; And of Abimelech, Whose Lust Could Not Harm Sarah's Chastity.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 30:2
verses.text: After this promise Lot was delivered out of Sodom, and a fiery rain from heaven turned into ashes that whole region of the impious city, where custom had made sodomy as prevalent as laws have elsewhere made other kinds of wickedness.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 30:3
verses.text: But this punishment of theirs was a specimen of the divine judgment to come.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 30:4
verses.text: For what is meant by the angels forbidding those who were delivered to look back, but that we are not to look back in heart to the old life which, being regenerated through grace, we have put off, if we think to escape the last judgment? Lot's wife, indeed, when she looked back, remained, and, being turned into salt, furnished to believing men a condiment by which to savor somewhat the warning to be drawn from that example.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 30:5
verses.text: Then Abraham did again at Gerar, with Abimelech the king of that city, what he had done in Egypt about his wife, and received her back untouched in the same way.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 30:6
verses.text: On this occasion, when the king rebuked Abraham for not saying she was his wife, and calling her his sister, he explained what he had been afraid of, and added this further, "And yet indeed she is my sister by the father's side, but not by the mother's; for she was Abraham's sister by his own father, and so near of kin.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 30:7
verses.text: But her beauty was so great, that even at that advanced age she could be fallen in love with.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 31

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 31:1
verses.text: Chapter 31—Of Isaac, Who Was Born According to the Promise, Whose Name Was Given on Account of the Laughter of Both Parents.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 31:2
verses.text: After these things a son was born to Abraham, according to God's promise, of Sarah, and was called Isaac, which means laughter.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 31:3
verses.text: For his father had laughed when he was promised to him, in wondering delight, and his mother, when he was again promised by those three men, had laughed, doubting for joy; yet she was blamed by the angel because that laughter, although it was for joy, yet was not full of faith.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 31:4
verses.text: Afterwards she was confirmed in faith by the same angel.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 31:5
verses.text: From this, then, the boy got his name.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 31:6
verses.text: For when Isaac was born and called by that name, Sarah showed that her laughter was not that of scornful reproach, but that of joyful praise; for she said, "God hath made me to laugh, so that every one who hears will laugh with  me".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 31:7
verses.text: Then in a little while the bond maid was cast out of the house with her son; and, according to the apostle, these two women signify the old and new covenants,—Sarah representing that of the Jerusalem which is above, that is, the city of God.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:1
verses.text: Chapter 32—Of Abraham's Obedience and Faith, Which Were Proved by the Offering Up, of His Son in Sacrifice, and of Sarah's Death.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:2
verses.text: Among other things, of which it would take too long time to mention the whole, Abraham was tempted about the offering up of his well-beloved son Isaac, to prove his pious obedience, and so make it known to the world, not to God.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:3
verses.text: Now every temptation is not blame-worthy; it may even be praise-worthy, because it furnishes probation.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:4
verses.text: And, for the most part, the human mind cannot attain to self-knowledge otherwise than by making trial of its powers through temptation, by some kind of experimental and not merely verbal self-interrogation; when, if it has acknowledged the gift of God, it is pious, and is consolidated by steadfast grace and not puffed up by vain boasting.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:5
verses.text: Of course Abraham could never believe that God delighted in human sacrifices; yet when the divine commandment thundered, it was to be obeyed, not disputed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:6
verses.text: Yet Abraham is worthy of praise, because he all along believed that his son, on being offered up, would rise again; for God had said to him, when he was unwilling to fulfill his wife's pleasure by casting out the bond maid and her son, "In Isaac shall thy seed be called".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:7
verses.text: No doubt He then goes on to say, "And as for the son of this bond woman, I will make him a great nation, because he is thy seed".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:8
verses.text: How then is it said "In Isaac shall thy seed be called," when God calls Ishmael also his seed? The apostle, in explaining this, says, "In Isaac shall thy seed be called, that is, they which are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God: but the children of the promise are counted for the seed".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:9
verses.text: In order, then, that the children of the promise may be the seed of Abraham, they are called in Isaac, that is, are gathered together in Christ by the call of grace.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:10
verses.text: Therefore the father, holding fast from the first the promise which behoved to be fulfilled through this son whom God had ordered him to slay, did not doubt that he whom he once thought it hopeless he should ever receive would be restored to him when he had offered him up.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:11
verses.text: It is in this way the passage in the Epistle to the Hebrews is also to be understood and explained.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:12
verses.text: "By faith," he says, "Abraham overcame, when tempted about Isaac: and he who had received the promise offered up his only son, to whom it was said, In Isaac shall thy seed be called: thinking that God was able to raise him up, even from the dead;" therefore he has added, "from whence also he received him in a similitude".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:13
verses.text: In whose similitude but His of whom the apostle says, "He that spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all?" And on this account Isaac also himself carried to the place of sacrifice the wood on which he was to be offered up, just as the Lord Himself carried His own cross.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:14
verses.text: Finally, since Isaac was not to be slain, after his father was forbidden to smite him, who was that ram by the offering of which that sacrifice was completed with typical blood? For when Abraham saw him, he was caught by the horns in a thicket.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:15
verses.text: What, then, did he represent but Jesus, who, before He was offered up, was crowned with thorns by the Jews?  But let us rather hear the divine words spoken through the angel.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:16
verses.text: For the Scripture says, "And Abraham stretched forth his hand to take the knife, that he might slay his son.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:17
verses.text: And the Angel of the Lord called unto him from heaven, and said, Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:18
verses.text: And he said, Here am I.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:19
verses.text: And he said, Lay not thine hand upon the lad, neither do thou anything unto him: for now I know that thou fearest God, and hast not spared thy beloved son for my sake".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:20
verses.text: It is said, "Now I know," that is, Now I have made to be known; for God was not previously ignorant of this.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:21
verses.text: Then, having offered up that ram instead of Isaac his son, "Abraham," as we read, "called the name of that place The Lord seeth: as they say this day, In the mount the Lord hath appeared".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:22
verses.text: As it is said, "Now I know," for Now I have made to be known, so here, "The Lord sees," for The Lord hath appeared, that is, made Himself to be seen.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:23
verses.text: "And the Angel of the Lord called unto Abraham from heaven the second time, saying, By myself have I sworn, saith the Lord; because thou hast done this thing, and hast not spared thy beloved son for my sake; that in blessing I will bless thee, and in multiplying I will multiply thy seed as the stars of heaven, and as the sand which is upon the seashore; and thy seed shall possess by inheritance the cities of the adversaries: and in thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed; because thou  hast obeyed my voice".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:24
verses.text: In this manner is that promise concerning the calling of the nations in the seed of Abraham confirmed even by the oath of God, after that burnt-offering which typified Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:25
verses.text: For He had often promised, but never sworn.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:26
verses.text: And what is the oath of God, the true and faithful, but a confirmation of the promise, and a certain reproof to the unbelieving?  After these things Sarah died, in the 127th year of her life, and the 137th of her husband for he was ten years older than she, as he himself says, when a son is promised to him by her: "Shall a son be born to me that am an hundred years old? and shall Sarah, that is ninety years old, bear?" Then Abraham bought a field, in which he buried his wife.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 32:27
verses.text: And then, according to Stephen's account, he was settled in that land, entering then on actual possession of it,—that is, after the death of his father, who is inferred to have died two years before.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 33

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 33:1
verses.text: Chapter 33—Of Rebecca, the Grand-Daughter of Nahor, Whom Isaac Took to Wife.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 33:2
verses.text: Isaac married Rebecca, the grand-daughter of Nahor, his father's brother, when he was forty years old, that is, in the 140th year of his father's life, three years after his mother's death.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 33:3
verses.text: Now when a servant was sent to Mesopotamia by his father to fetch her, and when Abraham said to that servant, "Put thy hand under my thigh, and I will make thee swear by the Lord, the God of heaven, and the Lord of the earth, that thou shalt not take a wife unto my son Isaac of the daughters of the Canaanites," what else was pointed out by this, but that the Lord, the God of heaven, and the Lord of the earth, was to come in the flesh which was to be derived from that thigh? Are these small tokens of the foretold truth which we see fulfilled in Christ?.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:1
verses.text: Chapter 34—What is Meant by Abraham's Marrying Keturah After Sarah's Death.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:2
verses.text: What did Abraham mean by marrying Keturah after Sarah's death? Far be it from us to suspect him of incontinence, especially when he had reached such an age and such sanctity of faith.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:3
verses.text: Or was he still seeking to beget children, though he held fast, with most approved faith, the promise of God that his children should be multiplied out of Isaac as the stars of heaven and the dust of the earth? And yet, if Hagar and Ishmael, as the apostle teaches us, signified the carnal people of the old covenant, why may not Keturah and her sons also signify the carnal people who think they belong to the new covenant? For both are called both the wives and the concubines of Abraham; but Sarah is never called a concubine (but only a wife).

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:4
verses.text: For when Hagar is given to Abraham, it is written.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:5
verses.text: "And Sarai, Abram's wife, took Hagar the Egyptian, her handmaid, after Abraham had dwelt ten years in the land of Canaan, and gave her to her husband Abram to be his wife".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:6
verses.text: And of Keturah, whom he took after Sarah's departure, we read, "Then again Abraham took a wife, whose name was Keturah".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:7
verses.text: Lo! both are called wives, yet both are found to have been concubines; for the Scripture afterward says, "And Abraham gave his whole estate unto Isaac his son.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:8
verses.text: But unto the sons of his concubines Abraham gave gifts, and sent them away from his son Isaac, (while he yet lived,) eastward, unto the east country".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:9
verses.text: Therefore the sons of the concubines, that is, the heretics and the carnal Jews, have some gifts, but do not attain the promised kingdom; "For they which are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God: but the children of the promise are counted for the seed, of whom it was said, In Isaac shall thy seed be called".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:10
verses.text: For I do not see why Keturah, who was married after the wife's death, should be called a concubine, except on account of this mystery.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:11
verses.text: But if any one is unwilling to put such meanings on these things, he need not calumniate Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 34:12
verses.text: For what if even this was provided against the heretics who were to be the opponents of second marriages, so that it might be shown that it was no sin in the case of the father of many nations himself, when, after his wife's death, he married again? And Abraham died when he was 175 years old, so that he left his son Isaac seventy-five years old, having begotten him when 100 years old.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35:1
verses.text: Chapter 35—What Was Indicated by the Divine Answer About the Twins Still Shut Up in the Womb of Rebecca Their Mother.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35:2
verses.text: Let us now see how the times of the city of God run on from this point among Abraham's descendants.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35:3
verses.text: In the time from the first year of Isaac's life to the seventieth, when his sons were born, the only memorable thing is, that when he prayed God that his wife, who was barren, might bear, and the Lord granted what he sought, and she conceived, the twins leapt while still enclosed in her womb.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35:4
verses.text: And when she was troubled by this struggle, and  inquired of the Lord, she received this answer: "Two nations are in thy womb, and two manner of people shall be separated from thy bowels; and the one people shall overcome the other people, and the elder shall serve the younger".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35:5
verses.text: The Apostle Paul would have us understand this as a great instance of grace; for the children being not yet born, neither having done any good or evil, the younger is chosen without any good desert and the elder is rejected, when beyond doubt, as regards original sin, both were alike, and as regards actual sin, neither had any.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35:6
verses.text: But the plan of the work on hand does not permit me to speak more fully of this matter now, and I have said much about it in other works.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35:7
verses.text: Only that saying, "The elder shall serve the younger," is understood by our writers, almost without exception, to mean that the elder people, the Jews, shall serve the younger people, the Christians.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 35:8
verses.text: And truly, although this might seem to be fulfilled in the Idumean nation, which was born of the elder (who had two names, being called both Esau and Edom, whence the name Idumeans), because it was afterwards to be overcome by the people which sprang from the younger, that is, by the Israelites, and was to become subject to them; yet it is more suitable to believe that, when it was said, "The one people shall overcome the other people, and the elder shall serve the younger," that prophecy meant some greater thing; and what is that except what is evidently fulfilled in the Jews and Christians?.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:1
verses.text: Chapter 36—Of the Oracle and Blessing Which Isaac Received, Just as His Father Did, Being Beloved for His Sake.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:2
verses.text: Isaac also received such an oracle as his father had often received.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:3
verses.text: Of this oracle it is thus written: "And there was a famine over the land, beside the first famine that was in the days of Abraham.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:4
verses.text: And Isaac went unto Abimelech king of the Philistines unto Gerar.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:5
verses.text: And the Lord appeared unto him, and said, Go not down into Egypt; but dwell in the land which I shall tell thee of.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:6
verses.text: And abide in this land, and I will be with thee, and will bless thee: unto thee and unto thy seed I will give all this land; and I will establish mine oath, which I sware unto Abraham thy father: and I will multiply thy seed as the stars of heaven, and will give unto thy seed all this land: and in thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed; because that Abraham thy father obeyed my voice, and kept my precepts, my commandments, my righteousness, and my laws".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:7
verses.text: This patriarch neither had another wife, nor any concubine, but was content with the twin-children begotten by one act of generation.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:8
verses.text: He also was afraid, when he lived among strangers, of being brought into danger owing to the beauty of his wife, and did like his father in calling her his sister, and not telling that she was his wife; for she was his near blood-relation by the father's and mother's side.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:9
verses.text: She also remained untouched by the strangers, when it was known she was his wife.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:10
verses.text: Yet we ought not to prefer him to his father because he knew no woman besides his one wife.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:11
verses.text: For beyond doubt the merits of his father's faith and obedience were greater, inasmuch as God says it is for his sake He does Isaac good: "In thy seed," He says, "shall all the nations of the earth be blessed, because that Abraham thy father obeyed my voice, and kept my precepts, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:12
verses.text: And again in another oracle He says, "I am the God of Abraham thy father: fear not, for I am with thee, and will bless thee, and multiply thy seed for my servant Abraham's sake".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:13
verses.text: So that we must understand how chastely Abraham acted, because imprudent men, who seek some support for their own wickedness in the Holy Scriptures, think he acted through lust.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:14
verses.text: We may also learn this, not to compare men by single good things, but to consider everything in each; for it may happen that one man has something in his life and character in which he excels another, and it may be far more excellent than that in which the other excels him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:15
verses.text: And thus, according to sound and true judgment, while continence is preferable to marriage, yet a believing married man is better than a continent unbeliever; for the unbeliever is not only less praiseworthy, but is even highly detestable.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:16
verses.text: We must conclude, then, that both are good; yet so as to hold that the married man who is most faithful and most obedient is certainly better than the continent man whose faith and obedience are less.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 36:17
verses.text: But if equal in other things, who would hesitate to prefer the continent man to the married?.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:1
verses.text: Chapter 37—Of the Things Mystically Prefigured in Esau and Jacob.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:2
verses.text: Isaac's two sons, Esau and Jacob, grew up together.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:3
verses.text: The primacy of the elder was transferred to the younger by a bargain and agreement between them, when the elder immoderately lusted after the lentiles the younger had prepared for food, and for that price sold his birthright to him, confirming it  with an oath.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:4
verses.text: We learn from this that a person is to be blamed, not for the kind of food he eats, but for immoderate greed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:5
verses.text: Isaac grew old, and old age deprived him of his eyesight.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:6
verses.text: He wished to bless the elder son, and instead of the elder, who was hairy, unwittingly blessed the younger, who put himself under his father's hands, having covered himself with kid-skins, as if bearing the sins of others.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:7
verses.text: Lest we should think this guile of Jacob's was fraudulent guile, instead of seeking in it the mystery of a great thing, the Scripture has predicted in the words just before, "Esau was a cunning hunter, a man of the field; and Jacob was a simple man, dwelling at home".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:8
verses.text: Some of our writers have interpreted this, "without guile".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:9
verses.text: But whether the Greek ἄλαστος means "without guile," or "simple," or rather "without reigning," in the receiving of that blessing what is the guile of the man without guile? What is the guile of the simple, what the fiction of the man who does not lie, but a profound mystery of the truth? But what is the blessing itself? "See," he says, "the smell of my son is as the smell of a full field which the Lord hath blessed: therefore God give thee of the dew of heaven, and of the fruitfulness of the earth, and plenty of corn and wine: let nations serve thee, and princes adore thee: and be lord of thy brethren, and let thy father's sons adore thee: cursed be he that curseth thee, and blessed be he that blesseth thee".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:10
verses.text: The blessing of Jacob is therefore a proclamation of Christ to all nations.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:11
verses.text: It is this which has come to pass, and is now being fulfilled.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:12
verses.text: Isaac is the law and the prophecy: even by the mouth of the Jews Christ is blessed by prophecy as by one who knows not, because it is itself not understood.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:13
verses.text: The world like a field is filled with the odor of Christ's name: His is the blessing of the dew of heaven, that is, of the showers of divine words; and of the fruitfulness of the earth, that is, of the gathering together of the peoples: His is the plenty of corn and wine, that is, the multitude that gathers bread and wine in the sacrament of His body and blood.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:14
verses.text: Him the nations serve, Him princes adore.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:15
verses.text: He is the Lord of His brethren, because His people rules over the Jews.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:16
verses.text: Him His Father's sons adore, that is, the sons of Abraham according to faith; for He Himself is the son of Abraham according to the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:17
verses.text: He is cursed that curseth Him, and he that blesseth Him is blessed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:18
verses.text: Christ, I say, who is ours is blessed, that is, truly spoken of out of the mouths of the Jews, when, although erring, they yet sing the law and the prophets, and think they are blessing another for whom they erringly hope.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:19
verses.text: So, when the elder son claims the promised blessing, Isaac is greatly afraid, and wonders when he knows that he has blessed one instead of the other, and demands who he is; yet he does not complain that he has been deceived, yea, when the great mystery is revealed to him, in his secret heart he at once eschews anger, and confirms the blessing.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 37:20
verses.text: "Who then," he says, "hath hunted me venison, and brought it me, and I have eaten of all before thou camest, and have blessed him, and he shall be blessed?" Who would not rather have expected the curse of an angry man here, if these things had been done in an earthly manner, and not by inspiration from above? O things done, yet done prophetically; on the earth, yet celestially; by men, yet divinely! If everything that is fertile of so great mysteries should be examined carefully, many volumes would be filled; but the moderate compass fixed for this work compels us to hasten to other things.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:1
verses.text: Chapter 38—Of Jacob's Mission to Mesopotamia to Get a Wife, and of the Vision Which He Saw in a Dream by the Way, and of His Getting Four Women When He Sought One Wife.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:2
verses.text: Jacob was sent by his parents to Mesopotamia that he might take a wife there.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:3
verses.text: These were his father's words on sending him: "Thou shall not take a wife of the daughters of the Canaanites.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:4
verses.text: Arise, fly to Mesopotamia, to the house of Bethuel, thy mother's father, and take thee a wife from thence of the daughters of Laban thy mother's brother.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:5
verses.text: And my God bless thee, and increase thee, and multiply thee; and thou shalt be an assembly of peoples; and give to thee the blessing of Abraham thy father, and to thy seed after thee; that thou mayest inherit the land wherein thou dwellest, which God gave unto Abraham".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:6
verses.text: Now we understand here that the seed of Jacob is separated from Isaac's other seed which came through Esau.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:7
verses.text: For when it is said, "In Isaac shall thy seed be called," by this seed is meant solely the city of God; so that from it is separated Abraham's other seed, which was in the son of the bond woman, and which was to be in the sons of Keturah.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:8
verses.text: But until now it had been uncertain regarding Isaac's twin-sons whether that blessing belonged to both or only to one of them; and if to one, which of them it was.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:9
verses.text: This is now declared when Jacob is  prophetically blessed by his father, and it is said to him, "And thou shalt be an assembly of peoples, and God give to thee the blessing of Abraham thy father".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:10
verses.text: When Jacob was going to Mesopotamia, he received in a dream an oracle, of which it is thus written: "And Jacob went out from the well of the oath, and went to Haran.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:11
verses.text: And he came to a place, and slept there, for the sun was set; and he took of the stones of the place, and put them at his head, and slept in that place, and dreamed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:12
verses.text: And behold a ladder set up on the earth, and the top of it reached to heaven; and the angels of God ascended and descended by it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:13
verses.text: And the Lord stood above it, and said, I am the God of Abraham thy father, and the God of Isaac; fear not: the land whereon thou sleepest, to thee will I give it, and to thy seed; and thy seed shall be as the dust of the earth; and it shall be spread abroad to the sea, and to Africa, and to the north, and to the east: and all the tribes of the earth shall be blessed in thee and in thy seed.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:14
verses.text: And, behold, I am with thee, to keep thee in all thy way wherever thou goest, and I will bring thee back into this land; for I will not leave thee, until I have done all which I have spoken to thee of.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:15
verses.text: And Jacob awoke out of his sleep, and said, Surely the Lord is in this place, and I knew it not.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:16
verses.text: And he was afraid, and said, How dreadful is this place! this is none other but the house of God, and this is the gate of heaven.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:17
verses.text: And Jacob arose, and took the stone that he had put under his head there, and set it up for a memorial, and poured oil upon the top of it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:18
verses.text: And Jacob called the name of that place the house of God".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:19
verses.text: This is prophetic.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:20
verses.text: For Jacob did not pour oil on the stone in an idolatrous way, as if making it a god; neither did he adore that stone, or sacrifice to it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:21
verses.text: But since the name of Christ comes from the chrism or anointing, something pertaining to the great mystery was certainly represented in this.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:22
verses.text: And the Saviour Himself is understood to bring this latter to remembrance in the gospel, when He says of Nathanael, "Behold an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile!" because Israel who saw this vision is no other than Jacob.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:23
verses.text: And in the same place He says, "Verily, verily, I say unto you, Ye shall see heaven open, and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of man".

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:24
verses.text: Jacob went on to Mesopotamia to take a wife from thence.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:25
verses.text: And the divine Scripture points out how, without unlawfully desiring any of them, he came to have four women, of whom he begat twelve sons and one daughter; for he had come to take only one.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:26
verses.text: But when one was falsely given him in place of the other, he did not send her away after unwittingly using her in the night, lest he should seem to have put her to shame; but as at that time, in order to multiply posterity, no law forbade a plurality of wives, he took her also to whom alone he had promised marriage.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:27
verses.text: As she was barren, she gave her handmaid to her husband that she might have children by her; and her elder sister did the same thing in imitation of her, although she had borne, because she desired to multiply progeny.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:28
verses.text: We do not read that Jacob sought any but one, or that he used many, except for the purpose of begetting offspring, saving conjugal rights; and he would not have done this, had not his wives, who had legitimate power over their own husband's body, urged him to do it.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:29
verses.text: So he begat twelve sons and one daughter by four women.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 38:30
verses.text: Then he entered into Egypt by his son Joseph, who was sold by his brethren for envy, and carried there, and who was there exalted.

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:1
verses.text: Chapter 39—The Reason Why Jacob Was Also Called Israel.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:2
verses.text: As I said a little ago, Jacob was also called Israel, the name which was most prevalent among the people descended from him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:3
verses.text: Now this name was given him by the angel who wrestled with him on the way back from Mesopotamia, and who was most evidently a type of Christ.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:4
verses.text: For when Jacob overcame him, doubtless with his own consent, that the mystery might be represented, it signified Christ's passion, in which the Jews are seen overcoming Him.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:5
verses.text: And yet he besought a blessing from the very angel he had overcome; and so the imposition of this name was the blessing.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:6
verses.text: For Israel means seeing God, which will at last be the reward of all the saints.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:7
verses.text: The angel also touched him on the breadth of the thigh when he was overcoming him, and in that way made him lame.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:8
verses.text: So that Jacob was at one and the same time blessed and lame: blessed in those among that people who believed in Christ, and lame in the unbelieving.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:9
verses.text: For the breadth of the thigh is the multitude of the family.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 39:10
verses.text: For there are many of that race of whom it was prophetically said beforehand, "And they have halted in their paths".

chapters.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 40

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 40:1
verses.text: Chapter 40—How It is Said that Jacob Went into Egypt with Seventy-Five Souls, When Most of Those Who are Mentioned Were Born at a Later Period.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 40:2
verses.text: Seventy-five men are reported to have entered Egypt along with Jacob, counting him with his children.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 40:3
verses.text: In this number only two women are mentioned, one a daughter, the other a grand-daughter.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 40:4
verses.text: But when the thing is carefully considered, it does not appear that Jacob's offspring was so numerous on the day or year when he entered Egypt.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 40:5
verses.text: There are also included among them the great-grandchildren of Joseph, who could not possibly be born already.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 40:6
verses.text: For Jacob was then 130 years old, and his son Joseph thirty-nine and as it is plain that he took a wife when he was thirty or more, how could he in nine years have great-grandchildren by the children whom he had by that wife? Now since, Ephraim and Manasseh, the sons of Joseph, could not even have children, for Jacob found them boys under nine years old when he entered Egypt, in what way are not only their sons but their grandsons reckoned among those seventy-five who then entered Egypt with Jacob? For there is reckoned there Machir the son of Manasseh, grandson of Joseph, and Machir's son, that is, Gilead, grandson of Manasseh, great-grandson of Joseph; there, too, is he whom Ephraim, Joseph's other son, begot, that is, Shuthelah, grandson of Joseph, and Shuthelah's son Ezer, grandson of Ephraim, and great-grand-son of Joseph, who could not possibly be in existence when Jacob came into Egypt, and there found his grandsons, the sons of Joseph, their grandsires, still boys under nine years of age.

verses.name: Augustine: City of God Book XVI 40:7
verses.text: But doubtless, when the Scripture mentions Jacob's entrance into Egypt with seventy-five souls, it does not mean one day, or one year, but that whole time as long as Joseph lived, who was the cause of his entrance.
